OWEB funds are budgeted for contracted services (construction – 38%), project management and engineering (15%), materials/supplies (23%), three years of plant establishment (11%) and fiscal administration.

In this application the Columbia SWCD, working with the Lower Columbia River Watershed Council and ODFW, seeks funding to hire an engineering contractor to determine the feasibility of addressing two private drive culverts together. The first option to be considered would be removal of one private drive crossing and the replacement of the other to achieve maximum fish passage. This first option would require the development of a new road linking the two private ownerships so the landowner whose crossing is eliminated can continue to access their property. If this option is not feasible, designs for replacement of both crossings will be produced to meet fish passage requirements and allow for natural watershed processes such as large wood and substrate movement. OWEB funds will be used for engineering designs to the 90% level, geotechnical engineering (combined engineering costs 75%), project management (12%) and fiscal administration.

This proposal would continue a project that has been useful in the Siuslaw basin over the course of the last thirteen years. The project will take advantage of opportunities to collect whole trees, logs and other materials for restoration activities, free of charge, from public and private properties. The materials are made available through storm events and land management activities (road building and/or land clearing). Project expenses are due to the need to collect the materials in a timely manner and transport them either to a restoration project site or to a storage site for use at another time. Up to $4,000 could be used to purchase logs at pulp or discounted prices. OWEB funds would be used for project management, transport of materials, log purchase and fiscal administration.

column8: Central Coast Watersheds Collaborative Restoration Assist.
column27: In this application, the Confederated Tribes of the Siletz Indians, Lincoln SWCD, Salmon Drift Creek Watershed Council, and the Siletz Watershed Council have joined together to increase their respective capacities to develop, fund and implement restoration projects on the central coast. The partners seek funding in order to contract for help developing eight restoration project proposals for submission in 2015. The funding will enable partners to conduct pre-project field work and project design, as well as draft project proposals and prepare contracts. Partner needs are similar and could be met through the shared retention of a highly qualified contractor who would help leverage funding match opportunities and move forward high-priority restoration projects, and by doing so the partners could realize economies of scale. OWEB funds will be used for Contracted Services (88%), project management (9%) and fiscal administration.

In this application, the Lower Nehalem Watershed Council (Council) requests funding to replace the current inadequate and failing two tidegate structure on McDonald Slough in the Nehalem estuary with a new tidegate system consisting of two 6’ X 6’ concrete box culverts equipped with muted tidal regulator (MTR) devices. The MTR devices will control the opening and closing of the tide gates and allow much longer periods where the gates will remain open each day, thereby providing many more hours when the Slough can function naturally and provide increased fish passage and utilization. Partners in the project include the landowner, Nehalem Marine, the Port of Nehalem, Pacific Shellfish Institute, ODFW, and DEQ. OWEB funds would be used for contracted services (62%), materials (21%), effectiveness monitoring (11% - $36,362), project management (2%), and fiscal administration.

This Effectiveness Monitoring project is intended to collect data to demonstrate the performance of the tidegate system to be replaced on McDonald Slough in the Nehalem estuary (OWEB restoration project 215-1017-11365). Specifically, this effectiveness monitoring project will monitor the gate duty cycles (time of openness), slough inundation levels behind the gate, and water quality parameters for temperature and salinity inside and outside the slough. The effectiveness monitoring will occur over a four year period, beginning immediately after completion of implementation of the companion restoration project, with two Interim Progress Reports and a Project Completion Report required.

column8: Siuslaw Salmon & Watershed Studies (aka Siuslaw Stream Team Extension IX)
column27: This application proposes to continue a unique watershed program in the Siuslaw Elementary School in Florence. After eight years, the program now provides classroom instruction and materials about the watersheds and natural resources of the area, and also provides guest speakers and 30+ field trips for approximately 700 students in grades 2-6, 8 and High School, including 20 teachers, in three different communities (Florence, Mapleton and Reedsport).  Emphasis will continue to be on hands-on experiences to introduce and reinforce watershed stewardship. Partners include the Siuslaw School District, the USFS Mapleton District, Florence STEP, ODFW, ODP&R, BLM, Siuslaw SWCD, the Siuslaw Watershed Council and family volunteers. OWEB funds will be used for project management (63%), travel (14%), contracted services (14%) and administration (9%).

column8: Salmon River Tributary Fish Passage Improvement
column27: Salmon Drift Creek Watershed Council (Council) is proposing to replace two undersized barrier culverts under Three Rocks Road, on the Salmon River estuary’s north bank. The Mink Creek culvert (#1) is located at MP 1.1 on Three Rocks Rd. The second culvert (#2) in this proposal is on an unnamed tributary to the Salmon River estuary, roughly 0.8 miles west of the Mink Creek culvert site. Culvert #1 (Mink Creek) will be replaced with a galvanized steel box culvert measuring 121” X 40”, and culvert #2 (un-named tributary) with a galvanized steel arch pipe measuring 64” X 40”. The Council is partnering with Lincoln County Road Department (owner of the culverts), USFS, ODFW, REEF Program Nursery, and Community Services Consortium (CSC –Natural Resource Crews). OWEB funds are budgeted for salaries (3%), contracted services (31%), supplies (57%), administration (6%) and post implementation reporting (2%).

Thompson Creek is one of two coho supporting tributaries to Devil’s Lake, a 680-acre natural freshwater lake connected to the Pacific Ocean by the 449 foot long D River at the north end of Lincoln City. There are a total of nine culverts on the mainstem of Thompson Creek, four of which are undersized and/or degraded or perched to the extent they block or delay fish passage. In this application the Council requests funding to conduct outreach to engage the necessary landowners and conduct an engineering study for all nine culvert locations. The study will include channel surveys of the following parameters: longitudinal profile for the channel reach; determination of the active channel width; and channel cross sections. For each culvert determined to need replacement an engineered design and budget will be developed for future submission to OWEB for implementation. Partners in the project include Lincoln County Public Works, Devil’s Lake Water Improvement District, and ODFW. OWEB funds are budgeted for salaries (5%), contracted services ($36,200) and administration (8%).

This application seeks to continue a project that has been both popular and successful in its previous ten years in the Siuslaw River basin. It would provide 13 days of “Watershed Camp” for approximately 50-60 students, broken into three sessions geared for: introductory campers (4 days), intermediate campers (4 days) and advanced watershed exploration campers (5 days). The Camps will be offered to students from grades 4 through 12. Camp workshops will focus on providing the campers with an overview of the need for watershed restoration projects as well as practical, hands-on experience with different types of restoration projects. Campers will study post-implementation restoration sites and work on active restoration project sites. Partners in the project include USFS-Mapleton District, Siuslaw School District 97J, BLM, private Foundations, local businesses, camper families, the Siuslaw SWCD and the Siuslaw Watershed Council. OWEB funds are budgeted for salaries & wages (29%), contracted services (33%), travel (28% - buses), and administration (10%).

The Salmon Drift Creek Watershed Council (SDCWC) works within the Salmon River basin, the Devil’s Lake watershed, and two significant tributaries (Drift and Schooner Creeks) that enter the Siletz River estuary in the town of Lincoln City. SWCWC has conducted a water quality monitoring program for the last 14 years. Portions of the Devil’s Lake system, Drift Creek, Schooner Creek and the Salmon River are on the 303(d) list for a variety of parameters (temperature, dissolved oxygen, bacteria, and pH). The monitoring accomplished through this proposal would support project planning and effectiveness monitoring to address these impairments as well as continuing collection of essential baseline and trend data for the area. Partners include DEQ, the Nestucca-Neskowin WQ Cooperative Laboratory, Devil’s Lake Water Improvement District, and SDCWC volunteers. OWEB funds are budgeted for project management (27%); lab analysis, DO sensor maintenance, data entry, analysis, and dissemination (39%); lab rent (8%); travel (5%); contracted services (2%); supplies (4%); and administration (13%).

The Siuslaw River is water-quality limited per 303(d) listings year-round for temperature and dissolved oxygen (RM 0 – 105.9) and for fecal coliform year-round from RM 5.7 to 105.9. Sediment issues are cited as one of the priority water-quality impairments in the basin. The Siuslaw Watershed Council has conducted a volunteer water quality monitoring program over the last 14 years. In this proposal the Council will use trained volunteers from communities throughout the basin and students from the Mapleton schools to monitor temperature, dissolved oxygen, turbidity, clarity, bacteria, salinity and tidal stage (estuary sites only), and weather conditions at sixteen sites. The long-term monitoring goals include characterizing water quality conditions for each fifth-field HUC in the basin, and using the data to target problem areas for restoration efforts. Partners in the project include the watershed council volunteers, DEQ, the Mapleton School District, and Surfrider Foundation. OWEB funds are budgeted primarily for project management (77%), travel (8%), supplies (5%) and administration (10%).

The area covered in this project includes the Salmon, Siletz, Yaquina, Alsea and Yachats River watersheds as well as numerous smaller direct-to-ocean tributaries. For the past eighteen years, the Lincoln SWCD (District) has employed two skilled aquatic habitat surveyors for a variety of tasks including conducting Aquatic Habitat Inventories (AQI) and spawning surveys of spring and fall chinook, coho and steelhead in the rivers and streams of the area. This proposal would fund the continuation of another year of AQI and spawner survey data collection and data entry by the same two surveyors and provide 100 hours for a surveyor assistant/trainee. Partners in the project include ODFW, NRCS, and the MidCoast Watersheds Council. 79% of the requested OWEB funds are budgeted for the surveyor wages; 7% is budgeted for surveyor mileage; 1% for supplies; and administration is budgeted at 13%.

column8: Restoring Ecosystems and Educating Future ("REEF" Conservation Leaders Program)
column27: The Salmon Drift Creek Watershed Council (Council) is requesting funding to continue its two year-old watershed education and conservation career development program. An anticipated 1,000 Lincoln City high, middle and elementary school students would be involved with Council restoration and water quality monitoring projects and native plant propagation at the Council’s nursery. The students would also have watershed ecology overnight camp at which they will present reports on projects on which they worked during the year. Partners in the project include the Lincoln County School District, ODFW, USFS, Lincoln SWCD, OSU Extension, Devil’s Lake Water Improvement District, City of Lincoln City, Gray Family Foundation, and others. OWEB funds are budgeted for project management (78%), travel (5%), rent (4%) and administration (13%).

column8: Mill Cr. Siletz Watershed Effectiveness Monitoring
column27: Mill Creek - Siletz is a 7th-field watershed that flows into the mainstem Siletz at RM 49 in the community of Logsden. ODFW operates a Life Cycle Monitoring station in Mill Creek and has been collecting data on abundance of adult salmonids and survival and downstream migration numbers of juvenile salmonids there since 1997. This current monitoring application would quantify the effects of a watershed-scale large wood placement, planned to be implemented summer of 2015, on fluvial geomorphic response, aquatic habitat, assemblage of benthic invertebrates, overwinter survival of juvenile coho, and overall coho smolt production for the watershed. The study is designed to inform future in-stream restoration priorities, large wood placement design, land use management, coastal coho recovery goals and objectives, and limiting factors analyses for coho salmon production. Partners in the project with the MidCoast Council and ODFW include Plum Creek Timber, DEQ, OSU, and the Confederated Tribes of the Siletz Indians. OWEB funds are budgeted for contracted services (48%); 2-person field crew for three aquatic habitat inventory (AQI) surveys and project support (30%); travel (2%); supplies (5%); 2 outreach workshops (2%); and administration (13%).

In this application the MidCoast Watershed Council (Council) proposes to provide watershed councils, land trusts, SWCDs and coastal city and county planners, working in each of Oregon’s 21 estuaries south of the Columbia River, with tools that will help identify, protect, conserve and restore lands that are expected to be future tidal wetlands under different sea level rise scenarios. The project will produce and deliver user-friendly GIS layers, maps, images and descriptions of priority areas for conservation specific to each estuary area and provide an outreach presentation to each targeted group to assure understanding of the information. Partners in the project include the USFWS Coastal Program and the Pacific States Marine Fisheries Commission. OWEB funds will be used for contracted services (84%), travel (2%), supplies (2%), and administration (11%).

In this application the Lower Nehalem Watershed Council (Council) is partnering with USFWS, Tillamook Estuary Partnership, Tillamook County Public Works, and ODFW to create an up-to-date comprehensive document describing road-stream crossings in the lower Nehalem River basin. The report would prioritize culverts for repair or replacement based on their potential to impede fish passage, impair stream function, and limit and degrade spawning and rearing habitat for salmonids. The resulting prioritized inventory will be distributed to the watershed partners and land managers for actual project development and implementation. OWEB funds are budgeted for salaries (46%), contracted services (18%), travel (21%), report publication (3%), and administration (13%).

This proposed project is part of the Tillamook Estuaries Partnership’s (TEP) Backyard Planting Program, and would occur on two different properties, owned by the same individual. One of the sites is on Foley Creek, roughly one mile upstream of Foley Creek’s confluence with the mainstem Nehalem at RM 7.5. The other site is on the southern bank of the mainstem Nehalem at RM 8.  The project would clear invasive species, plant native trees and shrubs, and conduct plant establishment activities for three years along 4,500 linear feet of the mainstem Nehalem River and along 8,000 linear feet of Foley and East Foley Creeks. Approximately 4,560 trees, 1,300 shrubs, and 10,600 willow cuttings total would be planted on the combined properties. The trees and shrubs would be protected, where necessary, with caging, tree guards and weed mats.   OWEB funds are budgeted for contracted services (76%), materials/supplies (18%), equipment upkeep (2%), and administration 3%.

column8: Clatskanie River Fish Passage Improvement Phase II
column27: Several years ago the Lower Columbia River Watershed Council (Council) identified six fish passage barrier culverts within the Clatskanie River’s headwater reaches that impaired juvenile and adult salmonids’ ability to reach the high quality habitat upstream. To date the Council has replaced two of the six culverts (numbers 2 and 3 working upstream) with open bottom structures 1.5 times the active channel width. In this new application the Council seeks funding to address site #4, where two side-by-side 6ft diameter culverts, in an 18ft active-channel-width stream, present a total barrier to juveniles and a partial barrier to adults. The plan is to replace the two undersized pipes with a 27ft bottomless arch culvert, a solution that will restore full passage for salmonids to a mile of spawning and rearing habitat upstream. Project partners include Columbia County Road Department, USFWS, ODFW and the Columbia SWCD. OWEB funds are budgeted for salaries (6%), contracted services (23%), supplies (59%), and administration (12%).

column8: Wallooskee Headwaters Fish Passage and Large Wood Placement
column27: The Wallooskee River is a significant tributary to Young’s Bay in Clatsop County on the northwest tip of Oregon. In this application the North Coast Watershed Association (NCWA) is partnering with Campbell Global/Lewis & Clark Timber to replace two undersized and perched fish passage barrier culverts and place 35 large wood structures in 1.76 miles of the headwater reaches of the mainstem Wallooskee and an unnamed tributary.. Both undersized culverts will be replaced with open bottom arched culverts sized to meet the 1.5 X active-channel-width NOAA requirement. The 35 large wood structures would be placed in the tributary reach downstream of the tributary’s culvert replacement and in the mainstem reach between the tributary confluence and the mainstem culvert further upstream. Partners in the project include Campbell Global/Lewis & Clark Timber, ODFW, and Astoria High School. OWEB funds are budgeted for salaries (1%), contracted services (45%), materials/supplies (41%), administration (13%), and post implementation reporting (1%).

The Lower Rogue Watershed Council currently has no action plan identifying restoration or protection priorities for the Lower Rogue River. This Technical Assistance grant proposal would build upon existing data and analyses, and bring together stakeholders to assist in the development of a Watershed Action Plan.

column8: Umpqua Estuary Tidegate Prioritization & Landowner Identification
column27: The Umpqua Estuary is a high priority area for tidegate repair, replacement, or removal due to a variety of social and biological concerns. This technical assistance grant will provide funds for USWCD and PUR staff to define private lands for tide gate projects, contact landowners. find a subset of owners willing to participate in restoration projects and prioritize sites for restoration.

column8: N. Slough, Catching Slough & Larson Slough Restoration Project Dev.
column27: This project development proposal will consist of development of project designs, permits, and funding proposals for on-the-ground restoration projects in three high priority sub-basins in the Coos watershed. The projects planned for implementation as a result of this grant will include riparian and wetland planting, fencing, channel reconfiguration, culvert replacement, and large wood and root wad placement.

The project proposes to address simplified stream conditions on Tioga Creek through large wood placement.  Tioga Creek is a large tributary stream that combines with Williams River to form the South Fork Coos River.

column8: West Fork Millicoma River & Buck Creek Restoration
column27: The project proposes to address simplified instream habitat conditions through the placement of large wood instream in the West Fork Milicoma and Buck Creek. Past management practices have simplified aquatic habitats within the West Fork Millicoma River and Buck Creek, located in the Coos River watershed.
The applicant proposes to develop designs to replace a fish passage barrier culver on Butcherknife creek, a tributary to Waters Creek in the Applegate River watershed.

The purpose of this project Is to strategically design instream restoration projects on Rice Creek which are intended to benefit coho and other native fish within 29 separate ownerships in the Rice Creek Watershed.Rice Creek, located in the Middle South Umpqua River Watershed.
The applicant proposes to remove a dam and restore the stream channel at stream mile 0.7 on the South Fork of Myrtle Creek located in the Umpqua River watershed.
The applicant proposes to improve simplified stream conditions by placing large wood structures in both Fitzpatrick and Sawyer Creeks,tributaries to the Upper and Middle Umpqua River.
The project proposes to enhance instream habitat on Lutsinger Creek by placement of large wood and boulders. Lutsinger Creek is a tributary to the Middle Umpqua River.
The project proposes to improve instream habitat conditions through the placement of large wood structures in Harrington Creek,a tributary to Rock Creek in the North Umpqua River watershed.
he project proposes to increase instream habitat complexity on three properties located along Munger Creek, a tributary to Williams Creek in the Applegate River watershed.
The project proposes to address degraded riparian conditions along Thompson Creek. Thompson Creek is a low gradient, perennial tributary or the Applegate River.

This TA application will catalogue restoration opportunities on 2,478 acres of predominately private ownership in the lower Elk River that includes 4 miles of mainstem channel and 5.7 miles of fish bearing tributary stream. The catalogued opportunities will be prioritized based on their cost-effectiveness and potential to increase complex rearing habitat; the highest priority sites will be designed and permitted.

This proposal integrates 10 water quality sondes into a real-time monitoring network in strategically placed monitoring locations within the Bear Creek and the Little Butte watersheds. Real-time monitoring at each location includes flow, temperature, dissolved oxygen, pH, conductivity, turbidity.

column8: 2016 and 2017 Umpqua Fish Eggs to Fry Program
column27: The project’s target audiences are first through fourth-grade students and their teachers. with moderate to low knowledge and understanding of the salmonid life cycle and habitat. The need will be addressed through partnering with ODFW's Fish Eggs to Fry program to provide teachers with the resources needed to effectively educate elementary-aged students about salmonids, their life cycle, and habitat needs.

column8: South Fork Coos River Aquatic Inventory Surveys
column27: This project will fund Aquatic Habitat Inventory (AHI) surveys in the South Fork Coos River and 9 of its named tributaries.Surveying will cover more than 44 miles of highly productive main stem and tributary habitat within the South Fork Coos basin.

column8: Rogue Basinwide Priority Barrier Removal Analysis
column27: This project proposes to hire a contractor to complete a programmatic feasibility analysis for moving forward with the removal of 33 priority fish barriers in the Rogue River watershed identified in ODFW's 2013 Statewide barrier prioritization and to recommend a systematic approach to address all of these high priority impediments to fish passage.

The project will develop a ridge-top to estuary restoration design for the Wasson Creek Management Area located in the South Slough National Estuarine Research Reserve.The project will target terrestrial and aquatic habitats, developing stream, wetland and riparian restoration designs, including channel re-meandering for the lowlands and silvicultural prescriptions.

column8: GHID Fish Passage Improvement Project, Phase 2
column27: This proposal  is the result of an OWEB TA grant and supports Phase II of the work to address fish passage issues at the Gold Hill Irrigation District Irrigation diversion dam and diversion facilities located on the Rogue River at river mile 122.5 near the City of Gold Hill. The preferred alternative will improve the fish bypass pipe system; move the headgate to the top of a long diversion canal, pipe the canal, limit diversions into the canal to our water right and eliminate year round diversions into the canal

column8: Sucker Creek Channel and Floodplain Restoration - Phase 3
column27: The project is located in Sucker Creek, a tributary to the Illinois River in Southwestern Oregon. A total of 42 key large wood pieces will be placed by an excavator to create a series of seven self-maintaining large wood complexes over a 1,500 foot reach of stream. The structures are designed to create pools, increase habitat complexity and increase channel roughness.

column8: Fielder and Wimer Dam Removal Project
column27: The project is located on Evans Creek, an important steelhead and salmon spawning tributary to the Rogue River. Fielder Dam is located at river mile 3 and Wimer Dam is located at river mile 10. This project will solve the fish passage problems associated with these two dams by removing the outdated structures. Fielder dam will be removed first and then Wimer Dam will be removed.

The project site stretches along both sides of 0.40 miles of Tenmile Creek, a tributary to the South Umpqua River. 0.40 miles of instream fish habitat will be enhanced in Tenmile Creek through the placement of  25 logs and 370 boulders placed instream using excavators

column8: Coos Watershed Hydrological, Meteorological, and Water Quality Monitoring, 2015-2016
column27: This project proposes to continue operations at four stream gaging stations and three weather stations in the Coos watershed and will collect data to continue to enhance and develop a data set large enough to perform meaningful statistical analysis to fulfill monitoring and assessment needs.

PUR’s Volunteer Monitoring Program has been strategically monitoring streams in parts of the Umpqua Basin since 2004.To build on past monitoring efforts, the application proposes to team with basin partners to share data and strategically choose new monitoring sites filling-in geographic data gaps. This effort will include prioritizing previously monitored sites and establishing reference sites for continued monitoring.

column8: Upper Umpqua River Restoration Planning Technical Assistance
column27: Seven tributaries to the Umpqua River near Elkton have been identified as high priority for restoration: Sawyer, Bultler, Heddin, Mehl, Waggoner, Fitzpatrick, and McGee Creeks. Project partners will provide technical expertise needed to assess conditions and design new project reaches. Project design will include individual log jam and boulder placement locations and materials needed.

This project is a continuation of a multi-year, basin-wide restoration effort to enhance fish habitat in the Camp Creek a tributary of the Umpqua River near Scottsburg in Southwest Oregon. This project work will continue to address limitations to salmon production in the drainage by placing 50 logs and 3,000 boulders throughout four miles of mainstem Camp Creek.

column8: West Fork Cow Creek Watershed Action Plan
column27: West Fork Cow Creek is a 55,914 acre 5th field watershed located in the South Umpqua sub-basin. The applicant is working to connect with all streamside landowners and other stakeholders in the basin to form a planning team to direct restoration prioritization. Priorities for work will be based off of a detailed survey of the current instream and riparian habitat and culvert surveys which rank the severity of fish passage blockages.

column8: Rogue Basin Riparian Assessment and Restoration Prioritization Project
Master Watershed Stewards: Connecting Communities Through Service-Learning
column27: The Master Watershed Stewards program targets Master Watershed Stewards targets 65 participants. This program provides hands-on science labs, interactions with natural resource professionals, career exploration, and stewardship service. Participants will be directly engaged in restoration projects. The goal of the project is to improve knowledge of watershed function and foster active stewardship of natural resources.

Curry County Watershed Outreach target audience is 1570 k-12 youth in Curry County. Activities include over 100 watershed lessons in combination with 30+ field trips to streams, 4 Adopt-a-Stream programs with a myriad of projects, and Stream Trailer outreach to Curry schools. A primary goal of this project is to inspire behavior change that will benefit watersheds, water quality, and salmon and steelhead habitat.

This 225-acre project in the Tualatin River National Wildlife Refuge Riverboat Unit and Metro River’s Bend property in Washington County is located in a Conservation Opportunity Area.  The Tualatin Basin Habitat Interconnect Project will implement priority actions identified in a watershed assessment and regional and state conservation strategies to restore interconnected, functional landscapes for recovery of at-risk native species.  Historic land conversion for farming and ranching removed native vegetation and altered hydrology with drainage tile installation and beaver trapping.  Proposed project will restore 75 acres of wet prairie/scrub woodland and 30 acres of riparian forest; and conduct plant establishment treatments on 120 acres of oak savanna, 75 acres of wet prairie/scrub woodland, and 30 acres of riparian forest.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, travel, grant administration reporting, and plant establishment.  Project partners include Tualatin River National Wildlife Refuge, Metro, VEGBAC, and Tualatin Riverkeepers.

column6: City of Corvallis Parks and Recreation
column8: Chip Ross Area Oak Habitat Restoration
column27: Project area is approximately 100 acres located adjacent to city limits in the City of Corvallis’s Chip Ross Park, Timberhill Natural Area, and OSU College of Forest’s Charlie Meadow.  Today only 2% of prairie and oak savanna habitat remains in the Willamette Valley, restoration is needed to increase and enhance this habitat type.  Proposed project will expand connectivity of oak habitat along a corridor that includes Bald Hill Natural Area, Fitton Green, Owen’s Farm, and USFWS Finley Refuge.  Oak savanna, oak woodland, and upland prairie habitats will be restored and enhanced by (1) thinning and removing Douglas fir and other competitive trees, (2) controlling invasive weeds, and (3) establishing native grasses.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services, and geotechnical report.  Project partners include OSU, Benton SWCD, USFWS, and City of Corvallis.

Dieckman Slough is a side-channel flowing through floodplain forests and commercial agricultural fields in the lower North Santiam River, just downstream of the City of Stayton in Marion County.  Lower Dieckman Slough lacks in-stream habitat complexity; and floodplain forests have been converted to commercial agriculture.  Resident and migratory fish species, including Chinook salmon, winter steelhead and Pacific lamprey, utilize Dieckman Slough for spawning and rearing.  Proposed project will restore off-channel habitat by installing in-stream large wood structure on ~3,100 linear feet and restoring floodplain vegetation on 24 acres.  This project builds on restoration occurring in the area, including: NRCS Wetland Reserve Program easements on a total of 331 acres; Hatch side-channel fish passage, in-stream and floodplain restoration; and recently purchased Chahalpam Wildlife area, a 338-acre conservation easement held by Grand Ronde Tribe.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, travel, materials and supplies, grant administration, reporting, and plant establishment.  Project partners include landowner, NFWF, FSA CREP, Yamhill SWCD, and North Santiam Watershed Council.

column8: Lower North Santiam Floodplain Restoration Alternatives Analysis
column27: Project will conduct a floodplain restoration analysis to determine a list of proposed floodplain restoration actions and preferred alternatives for the lower North Santiam River floodplain downstream of Stayton, Oregon.  Historic floodplain habitat and side-channels have been cut off from the mainstem flow by installation of revetments, culverts, and ditches placed to control flood waters, protect farm land, and to provide year-round water for agricultural and municipal uses.  The analysis will identify feasible and practical opportunities for reconnecting side-channels and historic floodplain habitats along Dieckman Creek, several unnamed tributaries, and along the North Santiam River between approximately river miles 12.5 to 14.6.  The Council, participating landowners, consultants, and a technical team will collaboratively identify and prioritize up to 3 floodplain restoration alternatives to incorporate into the hydraulic model to determine feasibility and potential for adverse effects to adjacent landowners.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services and grant administration.  Project partners include Spirit Mountain Community Fund, Meyer Memorial Trust, BLM, USGS, The Nature Conservancy, ODFW, USACE, Santiam Water Control District, landowners, and North Santiam Watershed Council.

column8: Bear Creek Fish Passage Enhancement Phase I
column27: Bear Creek, located in the Long Tom Watershed, is a Meyer Memorial Trust Willamette Model Watershed basin.  Bear Creek is a watershed council priority for fish passage improvements due to its proximity to the mainstem Willamette River and potential to provide habitat for juvenile upper Willamette spring Chinook salmon and Pacific lamprey once fish passage is improved.  This two-phased project will reconnect 7 stream miles by implementing fish passage solutions at 4 priority fish passage barriers.  The proposed phase 1 project will improve upstream passage to 4 stream miles by replacing 2 culverts located on private properties with bridges.  Survey and design work will be started for an ODOT culvert that is planned for implementation under the second project phase.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, travel, materials and supplies, county land use and permit fees, grant administration, and reporting.  Project partners include landowners, ODOT, and Long Tom Watershed Council.

column8: Graham Bottomland Oak Woodland & Wetland Prairie Hab. Restoration
column27: Project site is part of a 1,200-acre area of intact native habitats, including prairie, oak, riparian forest, and wetland located half-mile east of the Long Tom River north of Fern Ridge Lake in a Conservation Opportunity Area.  The site is located just south and east of properties on which the Council worked with landowners to restore rare habitats and associated species in partnership with USFWS and OWEB.  Less than one percent of wet prairie habitat remains in the Willamette Valley.  Proposed project will restore 20 acres of wet prairie, which includes a population of ESA-listed Bradshaw’s lomatium, and 10 acres of open oak woodland habitat.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, materials and supplies, county land use fee, grant administration, reporting, and reporting.  Project partners include landowners, USFWS, and Long Tom Watershed Council.

The BWCA Riparian Enhancement Phase II Project is located on the north bank of the McKenzie River between river mile 19 and 20, to the northeast of Springfield, Oregon.  This 16.5-acre project is located on three adjacent properties owned by the McKenzie River Trust, Lane County, and a private landowner.  Habitat for native species and general floodplain function at the project site has been altered by past on-site land use and impacts from basin scale factors, including multiple flood control and hydroelectric projects in the upper and middle sections of the watershed.  Proposed project will improve floodplain conditions and habitat for native species, such as Chinook salmon and Oregon chub, through management of invasive vegetation, planting native vegetation, and plant establishment over 5 years.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, materials and supplies, permits, grant administration, reporting, and plant establishment.  Project partners include McKenzie River Trust, EWEB, Springfield Public Schools, University of Oregon, and McKenzie Watershed Council.

column8: BWCA Riparian Enhancement Phase II - PE

column27: Technical assistance proposes to develop and adopt a 10-year watershed action plan for the McKenzie Watershed in cooperation with partner agencies and organizations, and the public.  Resulting plan will cover the entire watershed and include actions to conserve and restore fish and wildlife habitat, and to monitor and protect water quality.  It will also include field-based education related to habitat and water quality.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services for GIS, travel, printing, and grant administration.  Project partners include USFS, USACE, BLM, ODFW, Eugene Water and Electric Board (EWEB), Springfield Utility Board, Cities of Eugene and Springfield, McKenzie River Trust, Weyerhaeuser, International Paper, Wildish Sand and Gravel, Rice Family Farms, McKenzie Flyfishers, Northwest Steelheaders, Mohawk Watershed Partnership, Cedar Creek Partnership, McKenzie Schools, Lane County, Upper Willamette SWCD, McKenzie Watershed Council.

column8: Restoring Habitat Diversity to Mid-Valley Conservation Areas, Phase II
column27: Proposed project includes two locations, Bald Hill Farm in Benton County and Willamette Bluffs in Polk County; both of which have conservation easements and are located in Conservation Opportunity Areas.  Project addresses habitat loss and fragmentation, species diversity, and invasive species by restoring 68 acres of farm land and pasture to prairie, 8 acres of farm land to woodland, and 39 acres of degraded prairie, savanna and oak woodland.  This will improve conditions for federally listed Kincaid’s lupine, Willamette daisy, Nelson’s checkermallow, and Fender’s blue butterfly.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, materials and supplies, and grant administration.  Project partners include landowner, state wildlife grant, and Greenbelt Land Trust.

column8: Mid & Upper Marys Landowner Outreach and Rapid Bio-Assessment
column27: The Middle and Upper Marys River provides habitat for coastal cutthroat trout and Pacific lamprey as well as other native fish species.  The Marys River Preliminary Watershed Assessment recommended additional assessments be conducted to improve cutthroat trout distribution data and determine riparian area condition in relationship to land use.  Past Watershed Council work in adjacent areas have prompted strong landowner interest in the Upper Marys; however, the Council lacks ground-based understanding of habitat limitations in the Middle and Upper Marys River to confidently direct landowners to appropriate restoration strategies.  Technical assistance is needed to conduct a synthesis of existing information about the area, a field-based rapid bio-assessment to fill key knowledge gaps, and validate older and remotely-gathered data.  This assessment will provide landscape-scale understanding of watershed dynamics, limitations, and restoration opportunities that will be used to develop a map-based, prioritized restoration strategy in collaboration with landowners and funding partners.  This systems-based understanding of fish distribution and habitat potential will provide the Council a systemic understanding of highest value restoration opportunities prior to investing in landowner recruitment and site-specific projects.  OWEB funds are requested for staff; contracted services to support landowner outreach, field survey, data analysis, development and presentation of final report to the community and development of specific restoration proposals; travel; supplies and materials; and grants administration.  Project partners include landowners, Benton County, ODFW, USDA, Marys Peak Stewardship Group, and Marys Watershed Council.

Project is located on the lower Clackamas River, which is rearing and migration habitat for ESA-listed salmon and steelhead.  Past development along lower Clackamas River has reduced off-channel rearing habitat available to juvenile salmonids.  Proposed project will enhance river flood event resiliency, increase ecological habitat value for aquatic and terrestrial species, and improve water quality.  Off-channel habitat will be increased by reactivating the alcove and connecting the Clackamas River mainstem with the floodplain at lower flows, which will provide refuge and off-channel rearing habitat for threatened juvenile salmonids at critical life stages, refuge at storm flows, and late summer thermal refugia supplied by a 1,670-foot perennial stream that flows into the alcove.  Large wood installed in the alcove will provide some bank protection to the constructed channel and complexity for habitat benefits as well.  Restoring native trees and shrubs and managing invasive weeds will provide additional aquatic and wildlife habitat benefits across 32 acres.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, travel, materials and supplies, grant administration, reporting, and plant establishment.  Project partners include landowners, Clackamas County Parks, ODFW, OHSU, PSU, USFS, and Clackamas River Basin Council.

column8: Fisher's Bend Phase I - Alcove - PE
Middle Crabtree Creek Riparian Restoration - PE

column27: Crabtree Creek is a tributary of the South Santiam River that is spawning and rearing habitat for ESA-listed spring Chinook salmon and winter steelhead.  The lower and middle reaches have sparse, narrow and discontinuous native riparian vegetation.  This lack of fully functioning riparian buffer contributes to water quality concerns, including temperature and sediment loads.  Anadromous fish habitat is compromised by the lack of large woody material inputs into the channel and structure on the floodplain.  Proposed project builds on previous invasive weed control efforts by restoring native trees and shrubs on 42.5 riparian acres along 2.7 stream miles.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, travel, contracted services, materials and supplies, county land use fee, plant establishment, grant management, and reporting.  Project partners include landowners, Farm Service Agency, and South Santiam Watershed Council.

column8: Courtney Creek In-stream Habitat Enhancement & Culvert Replacement
column27: Courtney Creek flows through agricultural lands of the Calapooia Watershed and is a Meyer Memorial Trust Willamette Model Watershed basin.  Historically, this stream supported spawning and rearing habitat for Pacific lamprey, Chinook salmon, and winter steelhead.  Courtney Creek has limited in-stream large wood to promote stream channel processes that form habitat for native cold water fish, such as cutthroat and rainbow trout and lamprey; and has culverts that are fish passage barriers.  Proposed project will strategically place wood structures at 16 locations to restore stream channel processes that reconnect floodplain habitat, develop pools, and sort gravel; and replace two culverts with bridges to allow fish to access 6 stream miles.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, travel, materials and supplies, county land use planning, grant administration, and reporting.  Project partners include landowner, USFWS, Meyer Memorial Trust, and Calapooia Watershed Council.

column8: Morgan and Johnson Creeks Log Placement Project
column27: Morgan and Johnson Creeks are tributaries of McDowell Creek in the South Santiam basin, and primarily consist of private timberland, agriculture and rural residence land uses.  McDowell Creek is one of the few tributaries downstream of Foster Dam, which is a fish migration barrier.  Fish species in McDowell Creek include ESA-listed winter steelhead, resident trout and other native species; and potentially spring Chinook salmon and Pacific lamprey.  As part of the Willamette Model Watershed program, riparian and in-stream restoration projects have been implemented and monitored in McDowell Creek since 2008, which provided baseline information about stream conditions.  The lower portion of the basin exceeds state recommended water temperatures, and in the upper portion temperatures hover around the water temperature standard; and there is a lack of large wood structure throughout the basin.  Proposed project will place 28 structures with 210 logs at key locations in Morgan and Johnson Creeks to restore stream processes and improve connection of off-channel and floodplain habitats, pool development and maintenance, and gravel sorting throughout these streams.  The project area will be monitored for biological and stream channel changes.  OWEB funds are requested for project management staff, contracted services, travel, materials and supplies, land use form, grant administration, reporting, and effectiveness monitoring.  Project partners include USFWS, Meyer Memorial Trust and South Santiam Watershed Council.

Proposed project will establish or enhance native riparian forest along 1.7 river miles of the middle Luckiamute and Little Luckiamute Rivers in Polk County.  As a result of historic and recent land use practices, many stretches along one or both banks of the rivers have limited or no native riparian forest.  Degraded or absent riparian buffers are not well functioning and do not provide canopy cover, surface water filtration, habitat connectivity, or bank stabilization benefits to the rivers.  Noxious weeds are encroaching on existing vegetation and disrupting forest regeneration processes.  Water quality monitoring from 2011 to 2013 identified exceedances of various standards for turbidity, bacteria (E. coli) and nutrients on both rivers.  Establishing or enhancing 33.7 acres of riparian corridor along 1.7 miles of these rivers will expand the benefits to listed Upper Willamette steelhead, cutthroat trout, Pacific lamprey, and other native species.  OWEB funds will be used for staff, contracted services, travel, materials and supplies, land use page, grant administration, reporting, and plant establishment.  Project partners include DEQ, landowners, FSA, and Luckiamute Watershed Council.

column8: Expanding the Benefit-Luckiamute Riparian Revegetation - PE
Upper Crabtree Creek Watershed Fish Passage
column27: Proposed project is located in upper Crabtree Creek in the South Santiam Watershed where land is managed primarily by Weyerhaeuser and BLM.  Crabtree Creek watershed supports ESA-listed winter steelhead and Chinook salmon, Pacific lamprey, coho salmon, and resident trout species.  Project will address fish passage barriers on Crabtree Creek and Rock Creek, a tributary of Crabtree Creek.  An undersized, perched culvert at river mile 0.22 on Rock Creek blocks upstream fish migration to ~3 miles of spawning and rearing habitat.  The 1996 flood created a barrier waterfall at river mile 31.6 on Crabtree Creek that blocks upstream fish passage to 3.1 miles of designated steelhead Critical Habitat.  Project will replace the Rock Creek culvert with a channel-spanning bridge and construct a side-channel on Crabtree Creek to allow fish passage around the falls during adult steelhead migratory period.  At least 6.1 miles of fish habitat will be opened with the combined project sites.  Effectiveness monitoring will include snorkeling spawning surveys and physical habitat surveys.  OWEB funds are requested for project management, contracted services, travel, materials and supplies, land use approval, grant administration, reporting, and effectiveness monitoring.  Project partners include Weyerhaeuser, BLM, ODFW, and South Santiam Watershed Council.

The STEWARDS Youth Watershed Council program will target K-12 students in Sweet Home, Central Linn, Albany, and Lebanon.  Youth are engaged in civic and watershed enhancement activities as they learn about watershed ecology, watershed councils and how to create change in their communities through participation in democratic institutions.  The Youth Watershed Councils provide students with opportunities to learn watershed concepts, apply those concepts to identify and implement their own restoration projects, and train them for future watershed leadership.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, travel, materials and supplies, event refreshments, and grant administration.  Project partners include The Nature Conservancy, Gray Family Foundation, Calapooia Watershed Council, and South Santiam Watershed Council.

Bird Haven Tree Farm (BHTF) is a 217 acre parcel located along approximately 1 mile of the Lower North Santiam River, just upstream of the City of Stayton in Linn County.  BHTF is located in a high priority 15 river mile reach of the North Santiam River, near significant existing restoration and conservation efforts along the mainstem river.  Habitat types on BHTF include floodplain forest, side-channel habitat, historic oak savanna, and upland prairie.  Habitat condition is currently compromised due to significant disturbance, lack of management for several years and presence of invasive species.  Douglas fir plantations of varying age classes occupy much of the historic habitats.  Many resident and migratory fish species, including Threatened Upper Willamette River spring Chinook and winter steelhead, as well as Oregon chub and Pacific lamprey, utilize the North Santiam mainstem in this reach.  Quality off-channel habitat is a high priority restoration need in the North Santiam River documented in the draft Willamette/Lower Columbia ESA Salmon and Steelhead Recovery Plan and other planning documents.  Upland prairies still have the capacity to support grassland bird species, such as Oregon vesper sparrow and western meadowlark, while providing necessary pollinator networks.  Proposed project will improve fish access to nearly a mile of side-channel habitat, restore floodplain vegetation on 47 acres and restore upland prairie restoration on 40 acres.  OWEB funds are requested for project management staff, contracted services, travel, supplies and materials, land use approval, grant administration, reporting, and plant establishment.  Project partners include landowners, ODFW, USFWS, CREP, and North Santiam Watershed Council.

Milton Creek watershed drains approximately 34 square miles of Columbia County before terminating into Scappoose Bay.  Historically, this watershed was one of the most productive salmonid watersheds of Scappoose Bay; however, splash damming practices in the early 1900’s significantly reduced the amount of large woody debris and instream logs resulting in degraded habitat.  Proposed project will install wood and restore habitat along 3.2 stream miles.  This stream section was recently identified in a limiting factors analysis as an anchor habitat for coho smolt production, and also contains steelhead and cutthroat.  Lack of large wood was cited as a major limiting factor, with only 0.5 key pieces found per 100 meters.  An OWEB-funded Technical Assistance project identified 15 reaches within this section for large wood placement, and completed plans for wood configuration, stream access and material source.  A DEQ 319 grant will support non-native vegetation control and planting 6,400 native plants on 8.5 acres to increase biodiversity, reduce solar exposure and provide future large wood recruitment.  This large wood project and riparian planting will be monitored for three years.  OWEB funds are requested for project management staff, contracted services, travel, supplies and materials, grant administration, monitoring, and reporting.

Proposed project targets middle- and high school students from three school districts, university students and private landowners within four priority watershed areas.  Outreach through inquiry-based, field-focused activities is integrated with active watershed restoration, monitoring and enhancement efforts, and development of future projects.  Student teams with focus areas in water quality, stream habitat assessment, project survey, and restoration will collect data, assess habitat conditions, monitor restoration projects, and restore native tree and shrub plant communities.  Program activities and data are used for outreach to private landowners to develop voluntary enhancement projects.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, travel, printing, and grant administration.  Project partners include Springfield Public Schools and McKenzie Watershed Council.

column8: Upper Sandy River Habitat Restoration Project
column27: The Sandy River Basin Partners identified Salmon River and Still Creek as providing high quality anchor habitat for the basin’s native fish, and have prioritized these sub-watersheds for basin-scale restoration.  Sandy River salmon and steelhead populations have declined over the last century due to degradation of habitat and other factors.  Project will increase side-channel/floodplain connectivity on Salmon River and Still Creek.  Restoration actions include: reactivation of flow to 5 side-channels, construction of 29 large wood habitat structures, restoration of connectivity to one alcove, boulder placement, and placement of large wood in side-channel habitat and stream margins.  Post-project monitoring will follow construction to establish as-built conditions.  Physical habitat surveys will be repeated in summer 2015 and after bankfull events.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, travel, materials and supplies, grant administration, and reporting.  Project partners include USFS, BLM, City of Portland, NFWF, Pacific Power Blue Sky Fund, and The Freshwater Trust.

The Calapooia Watershed Council (CWC) and its partners, including Weyerhaeuser, US Forest Service, Oregon  Department of Fish and Wildlife (ODFW), private residents, and Environmental Protection Agency  Western Ecology Division, joined to form a technical advisory committee (TAC) to address monitoring and restoration needs for the Upper Calapooia.  While there has been research throughout the Calapooia related to water quality, flows and biophysical impacts of small dam removal, very little fisheries monitoring has taken place due to agency capacity limitations.  To inform future TAC discussions regarding headwaters restoration or future attempts by ODFW to jump-start the Chinook population through seeding, we must understand current production levels of steelhead and Chinook. With significant ODFW contribution, proposed project will perform 30-miles of spawning surveys for Chinook and steelhead as well as Pacific lamprey.  Also supported is a one-time upper Calapooia snorkel including side-channel habitats and spawning gravel survey.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, travel, materials and supplies, equipment, and grant administration.

column8: Lower Long Tom River Fish Passage and Floodplain Restoration Project
column27: The goal of the project is to begin planning holistic restoration of the Long Tom River between Fern Ridge Dam and the Willamette River. This reach of the River was channelized by the US Army Corps of Engineers in the 1940’s to reduce flooding, cutting its length from 36.5 to 23.6 miles. Three low-head dams were also installed to control the channel grade, blocking upstream migrations of important fish like juvenile upper Willamette River spring Chinook and Pacific lamprey.  OWEB funds will be used to perform floodplain inundation mapping, hydraulic/hydrologic modeling, and develop a community needs and opportunities analysis and restoration plan.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, travel, and grant administration.  Project partners include a private donor, USACE, McKenzie River Trust, community leaders, and Long Tom Watershed Council.

Proposed project includes three programs to engage students, teachers and volunteers in stewardship opportunities that promote individual and community responsibility for watershed health. Over 400 on-water volunteers will participate in the Down by the River Clean Up and Stash the Trash Campaign, 20-40 teachers will learn watershed-based curriculum, and 410 students will raise salmon in the classroom, toss carcasses into Clackamas tributaries, receive a watershed presentation, or engage in riparian restoration.  These activities promote active involvement in stewardship by providing hands-on learning opportunities through workshops, watershed presentations, salmon life cycle, riparian restoration, and river clean-up activities.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, supplies and materials, equipment, other costs, and grant administration.  Project partners include Clackamas County, Clackamas River Water Providers, Chrysalis Farm, ODFW, DEQ, and Clackamas River Basin Council.

column8: Coyote Creek South: Wet Prairie-Vernal Pool Restoration Phases 1 and 2
column27: Proposed project is located on Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife’s (ODFW) 309-acre Coyote Creek South property in the Long Tom Watershed among a complex of more than 8,500 acres of protected lands comprising the West Eugene Wetlands and Fern Ridge Wildlife Area.  Coyote Creek South hosts native riparian habitat; and intact and restorable oak savanna, ash swale, wet prairie, emergent wetland, and vernal pool habitat.  This area currently supports, or is capable of supporting, native plant species, invertebrates, and vertebrates partly or wholly dependent on native Willamette Valley habitats.  Proposed project will restore 116 acres in the northern portion of the property from agricultural wetlands to a mosaic of wet prairie and vernal pool habitat.  This restored habitat will support diverse native plant species, northern red-legged frogs and other native amphibians, and grassland birds, in particular federally threatened streaked horned larks.  Less than one percent of wet prairie habitat remains in the Willamette Valley, and habitat loss and fragmentation is the major limiting factor affecting prairie dependent wildlife species.  OWEB funds are requested for project management staff, contracted services for design and implementation, travel, supplies and materials, grant administration, reporting, and effectiveness monitoring.  Project partners include ODFW, USFWS, BLM, technical advisors, and Long Tom Watershed Council.

column8: Coyote Creek South: Wet Prairie-Vernal Pool Restoration Phases 1 and 2 - EM

column6: Friends of Buford Park & Mt Pisgah
column8: Meadowlark East Prairie & Oak Savanna Project
column27: Project is located in southeast portion of Lane County’s 2,363-acre Howard Buford Recreation Area near the confluence of Willamette’s Coast and Middle Forks and adjacent to The Nature Conservancy’s 1271- acre “Willamette Confluence Preserve.”  Buford Park contains one of Oregon’s largest expanses of publicly-owned “globally endangered” Willamette Valley upland prairie and oak savanna.  Decades of fire suppression have contributed to encroachment by Douglas fir.  In addition, invasive plant species have degraded native botanical diversity and wildlife habitat.  This project will restore and enhance prairie and savanna habitat across the 275-acre “Meadowlark Project” on Buford Park.  Management actions will: 1) restore oak savanna on 55 acres by removing native conifer (including Douglas fir) and hardwoods; 2) restore prairie on 31.5 acres by removing encroaching native conifer and small exotic trees; 3) enhance oak woodland on 21.5 acres by thinning fir and some hardwoods; 4) suppress invasive herbaceous and shrub species; and 5) broadcast seed mix of grasses and forbs in areas of invasive control and tree removal to enhance habitat diversity and forage for wildlife.  These actions are expected to benefit 17 at-risk species known to occur in the Mt. Pisgah area that depend on these prairie, oak savanna and oak woodland habitats, including Western meadowlark and acorn woodpecker.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, travel, materials and supplies, grant administration, outreach, and reporting.  Project partners include Lane County, BPA, USFWS, and Friends of Buford Park and Mt. Pisgah.

column8: Upper Deep Creek Fish Passage Design & Stream Recon Plan
column27: Deep Creek is in the closed Warner Basin, east of the town of Lakeview in Lake County. Warner Basin is a closed basin which supports federally listed species of concern, Warner redband trout, as well as endemic Warner Lake suckers. The watershed has been impacted by historic land use such as water diversion and stream channelization for irrigation purposes. A major issue is that fish species are trapped between a natural falls on Lower Deep Creek and a 32 ft. diversion weir on Upper Deep Creek located on the Robison Ranch. This project will provide Lake Creek Umbrella Watershed Council with a design for fish passage on the Robison Ranch diversion and information about aquatic habitat; additional fish passage barriers, irrigation efficiency issues, and restoration needs on Upper Deep Creek as well as six tributary streams. Partners include the landowner, ODFW, USFS Resources Advisory Committee, and Ducks Unlimited.

column8: MFID Temp Evaluation for Flow Mgmt. Strategies
column27: This project is located in Middle Fork Hood River sub-basin, a tributary to the Columbia River lying south of the town of Hood River. The project will evaluate the effects of proposed water projects, changes to diversion rates, and Laurance Lake reservoir management scenarios that impact water temperature in the basin.  The information obtained will be added to an earlier assessment of water flow in the basin, and will augment a planned analysis of fish barrier and passage issues. The data derived from this project has the potential to impact habitat for spring Chinook, winter steelhead, and bull trout, all listed as threatened under the ESA, as well as resident cutthroat trout in the Hood River system. Partners include ODFW and Confederated Tribe of the Warm Springs.

This project takes place north of Madras in the Mud Springs Drainage. Mud Springs enters Trout Creek two miles upstream of its confluence with the Deschutes River, just downstream of Warm Springs. The North Unit Irrigation District (NUID) diverts water from the Deschutes and Crooked Rivers to irrigate 59,000 acres of thousands of acres of pasture and crop land in southern Jefferson County.  Trout Creek provides the southernmost naturally-accessible habitat for steelhead in the Deschutes River watershed.  Additionally, the Pelton-Round Butte Dam (PRB) complex stops natural migration up the Deschutes River. Steelhead, Spring Chinook, and Sockeye Salmon are being reintroduced above the PRB complex. These returning fish are currently being trapped and trucked above the dams with most of the fish ending up in the Crooked River currently.      The two main issues being addressed by this project are water quality in the Trout Creek and Mud Springs watersheds, and instream habitat for fish in the Crooked River. There is sediment, phosphorous, and E. Coli associated with Trout Creek because of run off from uplands and agricultural land in both the Trout Creek and Mud Springs watersheds. Previous phases of this piping project have anecdotally been successful in taking care of runoff issues as many of the water users have converted to sprinkler pivot irrigation from flood irrigation. Water quality data needs to be provided in order to confirm current conditions. When completed, this project will also return an estimated .3 cfs (3.7 cfs from phases 1-6) of instream water per a conserved water allocation into the Lower Crooked River.      Partners in this project include Jefferson County SWCD, US Bureau of Reclamation (BOR), North Unit Irrigation District, Black Rock Consulting, and Portland General-Electric Pelton Round Butte Fund.

column8: Cold Springs Ranch Instream Restoration Design
column27: This project focuses on the reach of the Lower South Fork of the Crooked River that flows through the 16,000 acre Cold Springs Ranch located south east of Pineville, Oregon. This proposal will address six points of diversion and associated irrigation canals, irrigation return flow, fish passage, and fish screening. The irrigations system is inefficient and results in a loss of water and overland flow affecting water quantity, quality and access to instream habitat for native redband trout and other species on over 24 miles of stream. The landowner is the only financial partner with the applicant at this point; however, the applicant intends to include ODFW and OWRD in the analysis and restoration planning process.

This project takes place on South Fork Beaver Creek, Trout Creek, Camp Creek, and Grindstone Creek, all tributaries of the upper Crooked River located in Crook and western Grant Counties. At over 7,000 feet, the upper reaches of South Fork Beaver Creek Watershed are comprised of pine/fire forest pockets, western juniper, sage brush steppe, and wet meadow communities. Resource concerns are instream habitat for native redband trout and upland habitat for wildlife, including sage grouse, proposed for ESA listing. The entire project area is located inside ODFW core habitat area for sage grouse and within the EA for grouse. Due to historical land use practices, removal of beaver from large parts of the system, wild fire suppression, climate change, and many other factors there are a multitude of resource issues including eroded stream banks, headcutting of streams, noxious weeds, juniper invasion, overstocked woodlands, and sedimentation in streams, disconnected floodplains and loss of wet meadow complexes. Over the past 20 years, Crook County SWCD, Crook County Watershed Council, and other conservation and agency partners have been working with willing landowners on restoring the South Fork Beaver Creek Watershed.  They have completed most of those efforts, and the elements of this proposal represent the final projects left on properties with willing landowner in the basin. Spread out over 25,000 acres, this multi-landowner, multi-site project will construct 4 miles of riparian exclusion fencing, remove 4 miles of fence (wildlife hazard), build 20 artificial beaver dams, construct 15 off-stream water developments, convert ½ mile of irrigation from ditch to pipe, construct 4 sediment basins, remove 4,000 acres of juniper, conduct 200 acres of mixed-conifer and juniper forest health improvement, and treat 200 acres of noxious weeds.    Partners in this project include three separate landowners, BLM, ODF, NRCS and the Crooked River Weed Management Area.

column8: Cottonwood Creek Fish Passage and Garrett Ranch Wetland Enhancement
column27: This project takes place on Cottonwood Creek, a tributary to Thompson Creek which flows into Goose Lake (currently dry) in Goose Lake Basin, Lake County. Goose Lake Basin is home to at least seven endemic fish species, most of which are Oregon State Sensitive Species, and all can be expected to use the lower reaches of Cottonwood Creek as some life stage. Land use practices including overgrazing, diversions for irrigation (many unscreened), and extreme draught have all impacted riparian and aquatic habitat in the basin. This project will replace an old culvert and board diversion with an engineered pre-cast weir and fish ladder that will include a flow measuring device and a separate pre-cast screen box for future fish screen installation. There is no instream restoration occurring above or below this project. Partners in this project include the landowner and Ducks Unlimited.

This project is located on the uplands adjacent to Mill Creek sub-watershed, tributary to the Columbia River in The Dalles Watershed. This area contains The Dalles Municipal Watershed (4,784 acres) and provides drinking water for 13,783 residents. Mill creek is also home to Middle Columbia River steelhead, Chinook salmon, Coho salmon, Coastal cutthroat trout, and Pacific lamprey.  The area suffered damage during the 11,434 acre Government Flats Complex fire which burned dry herbaceous cover, Oregon White Oak, and Ponderosa Pine. The project will include aerial seeding of 148 acres, Ponderosa and Douglas fir planting on 458 acres, and establishment of 25 clumps of Antelope Bitterbrush. This project augments earlier work on the fire restoration site. Partners on this project include NRCS (possibly not funded, but there is plenty of match even if not available), Oregon Safe Drinking Water State Revolving Fund, Oregon Wildlife Heritage Foundation, City of The Dalles, DEQ, Wasco County SWCD, ODFW, ODF.

This project is located on the uplands adjacent to Mill Creek sub-watershed, tributary to the Columbia River in The Dalles Watershed.  Mill creek supports spawning habitat for Middle Columbia River steelhead, Chinook salmon, Coho salmon, Coastal cutthroat trout, and Pacific lamprey.  The site of this project is an old side channel that was plugged for flood control for agricultural property adjacent to the site. This project will address fish habitat and water temperature issues by improving stream connection to the historical floodplain, increasing floodplain roughness, and hyporrheic flow by reconnection of the side channel, removing a levee, grade control, replacing and inadequate culvert with a bridge, riparian planting, creating an alcove, and placing large woody debris instream.  The application includes pre and post effectiveness monitoring in conjunction with ODFW.  Partners in this project include ODFW, USFS, The Dalles Watershed Council, DEQ, and City of The Dalles.

column8: Lower Mill Creek Side Channel - EM
column27: This Effectiveness Monitoring project will accompany a side channel restoration project on Mill Creek in The Dalles watershed; a tributary to the Columbia River which hosts ESA listed steelhead from the Middle Columbia River Distinct Population Segment (ESU), as well as Chinook and Coho Salmon, and Costal Cutthroat trout.  Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife will conduct seasonal fish surveys within the created side channel habitat and just downstream of the project for one year prior to project implementation, and four years after project implementation. These surveys will determine seasonal fish presence and use of the restoration area. Survey methods will include spawning surveys, operation of a rotary screw trap just downstream of the project, and the installation for a PIT tag array to collect information on returning PIT tagged adults. Two additional temperature data loggers calibrated according to Oregon Department of Environmental Quality will be deployed within the side channel and upstream of the project for one year before and five years after project implementation.

column8: Lindell Dam Removal and Irrigation Efficiency Upgrade
column27: This project takes place on Tygh Creek, a tributary to the White River, which eventually flows into the Deschutes River. This project will remove a dam and move the point of diversion downstream to a modern direct diversion pump with a self-cleaning fish screen. Aging and leaky above ground aluminum mainline will be replaced with PVC pipe, and aging hand line and wheel line will be replaces with center pivots and low pressure rotator sprinklers. The project opens up 18 miles of stream to native redband trout.

column8: Crooked River Watershed Sage Grouse Conservation
column27: Funds will be used by the Crook Soil and Water Conservation District (SWCD) in partnership with Deschutes SWCD to develop site specific plans (SSPs) protecting sage grouse habitat on private range lands in Crook and Deschutes counties. These plans would then be enrolled into a multi-county Candidate Conservation Agreement with Assurances prior to a pending endangered listing of the sage grouse by United States Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS) to be determined by September, 15th, 2015. The SWCD will use existing relationships with landowners and new outreach activities in an effort to engage and enroll at least 30% (70 landowners) of landowners in sage grouse habitat in Crook in Deschutes counties in SSPs.  These plans include land management practices such as grazing management, riparian protection, rangeland restoration, weed management and others  intended to protect and restore important sage-steppe habitat which will be both critical to the long-term sustainability of sage grouse as well as other sage-steppe related species. Similar work has been done successfully in Harney County.

This project would establish a Youth Watershed Council among the Natural Resource Students of Culver High School.  Students would work both inside and outside the classroom, learning watershed science and restoration techniques, and conduction on-the-ground restoration activities in the McMeen Creek and Willow Creek drainages. This work would dovetail with ongoing and proposed restoration by the US Forest Service and Middle Deschutes Watershed Council (MDWC) in Jefferson County. MDWC and the school would partner with USFS personnel who have experience working with successful youth council models in the Willamette Valley to develop curriculum and projects associated with the youth watershed council.

column8: Willow Creek Upland and Riparian Enhancement
column27: Willow Creek is a tributary of the Deschutes River that flows into Lake Simtustus above Pelton dam. Above Madras, Oregon, the creek flows through a narrow canyon on Crooked River National Grasslands (CRNG). Despite downstream dewatering, passage barriers, and water quality issues, above Madras, the riparian area is largely intact and the creek supports a population of native redband trout and other wildlife including nesting bald and golden eagles. However, there are areas of heavy juniper invasion into what used to be sage-steppe uplands. MDWC proposes 1,850 acres of juniper treatment in the uplands alongside Willow Creek.  This project is a continuation of non-OWEB funded work downstream in the canyon.  Juniper will be cut and burned, and where appropriate, left in the creek to encourage stream complexity and provide instream habitat. Partners in this project include USFS-CRNG and Jefferson County SWCD.

Cottonwood Creek is a tributary to Thompson Creek which flows into Goose Lake (currently dry) in Goose Lake Basin, Lake County. Goose Lake Basin is home to at least seven endemic fish species, most of which are Oregon State Sensitive Species, and all can be expected to use the lower reaches of Cottonwood Creek at some life stage. Land use practices including over grazing, diversions for irrigation (many unscreened), and extreme draught have all impacted riparian and aquatic habitat in the basin. This project will combine two irrigation diversions to one of the existing points of diversion. The upstream structure functioning as the combined point of diversion will be replaced with a pre-cast weir and fish ladder.  The lower structure will remain to prevent headcutting, but will be made passable for fish and other species through grade control structures below the diversion. The structure will include a flow measuring device and a pre-cast screen box for future fish screen installation. Stream bank and channel restoration will be included in the project. Partners in this project include the landowner and Ducks Unlimited.

column8: Goose Lake Basin Stream Reconnaissance Plan
column27: Lake County Umbrella Watershed Council (LCUWC) will contract for a comprehensive stream reconnaissance plan to determine limiting factors and priority restoration projects on private stretches of twelve streams (180 miles) located in the Goose Lake Watershed, the largest basin in Lake County.  The USFW will conduct concurrent surveys on public lands. A similar survey was previously conducted by LCUWC on Thomas Creek, a major tributary to Goose Lake, and it has been used to successfully identify and plan restoration activities including improving fish passage, irrigation diversion replacement and screening, stream channel and riparian restoration, and grazing management along over 40 miles of Thomas Creek. Similar projects are expected as a result of this plan.

column8: Upper Thomas Creek Restoration Phase III
column27: Lake County Umbrella Watershed Council (LCUWC) will address the remaining twelve priority projects outlined for Upper Thomas Creek, a major tributary to Goose Lake northwest of Lakeview, OR.  Thomas Creek is home to multiple endemic species including redband trout and federally listed Modoc suckers.  Proposed projects will occur on private and National Forest land and will address fish passage, instream habitat, channel instability, bank erosion, riparian vegetation and grazing management issues.  Previous work has been done on Thomas Creek by Lake County Umbrella Watershed Council and partners including the US Forest Service, Lakeview Soil and Water Conservation District and Ducks Unlimited.  After the proposed work is completed, all priority projects on Thomas Creek will have been completed, enhancing over 40 miles of river from the headwaters to the mouth at Goose Lake. OWEB has been a funding partner on many of these projects.

column8: Crook County Natural Resources CTE Outreach Program
column27: This project is a continuation of a past OWEB grant (213-4028) for enhancement of a highly successful Career Technical Education – Natural Resource Management Program of Study at Crooked River High School. Students are taught watershed and restoration science and engage directly in restoration activities. There are 54 field days included in this project. The Crooked River Watershed Council (CRWC) works directly with the school to provide hands-on examples of the type of restoration concepts that students are learning about. The work performed and information gathered by the students is actually being used as part of project implementation and monitoring. This project has been extremely successful, both in engendering community support, but also in attracting media and congressional attention to the project. Graduates of this program have successfully obtained summer natural resource work in competition with college level applicants. This continuation of the project is focused on broadening the program to include elementary-age kids.

column8: Warner Ranch Wetland Enhancement and Fish Passage Project
column27: DU’s project will replace an earthen push up dam at the mouth of Drew’s Creek and Goose Lake with a concrete diversion including a fish ladder, providing passage at the only remaining fish barrier between Goose Lake and Drew’s Reservoir benefiting endemic Goose Lake Basin fish species.  In this unique system, and although the lake is currently dry, in wet years, connection to the lake performs an important function for the reproduction and rearing of endemic fish such as redband trout.
