They migrate out to the lake, grow rapidly and then return to the stream to spawn. It has been suggested by ODFW biologist that this periodic event is important to the persistence of fish species in the basin.

Big Summit Prairies is a private parcel surrounded by the Ochoco National Forest north and east of Prineville. It is comprised of high-elevation ponderosa pine forest, shrub-steppe uplands, wet meadow, and riparian areas along the banks of the North Fork of the Crooked River and associated tributary streams which feed the meadow system.  There are native redband trout and associated riparian wildlife found in the area. It is also an important area for elk. There is federal land and Wild and Scenic River designation both upstream and downstream of the prairie.  There are legacy resource issues related to homesteading the area (i.e., ditching, diking), compounded by years of poor grazing management.  Current ownership of eastern half of the prairie, approximately 9,000 acres, are interested in assessing the current state of the property and conducting restoration activities to address irrigation efficiency, floodplain connectivity, fish passage and screening, and erosion issues, among others.  They recently paid for a Proper Functioning Condition Assessment of their ranch properties.   CRWC will use this information to work with the landowner and agency partners to develop a restoration action plan that will address irrigation and grazing management, forest management, fish passage, stream/riparian function, and aquatic habitat. It is anticipated that multiple restoration projects will flow from this assessment and plan.

column8: Evans Creek Restoration and Culvert Replacement at Hutson Drive
column27: Hood River County intends to correct a longstanding passage barrier issue for Evans Creek, a tributary to the East Fork Hood River.  The creek is important in that clear (non-glacial) tributaries are rare in the Hood River Basin, and this is important spawning habitat for federally listed winter-run steelhead. There are currently a perched culvert at Houston Drive, and a buried culvert downstream that was part of an earlier failed restoration attempt. Fixing the perched culverts at Houston Dr. and removing the instream culvert and restoring the channel will open up an additional 1.3 miles of habitat for federally listed winter steelhead. There is additional habitat potential upstream with the completion of future culvert projects.

column8: Landscape Restoration of Upper Crooked River Basin
column27: The Nature Conservancy’s Juniper Hills Preserve lies in the Upper Crooked River Basin near Post, Oregon.   This project is part of a larger plan to restore 10,000 acres of sagebrush-steppe, dry pine, and forest-sagebrush and juniper woodlands on the preserve. Project components include pre-burn treatment and prescribed fire on 1,830 acres, juniper cutting on 1,030 acres, planting native seed with Precision Restoration techniques including new seed treatment (seed are encased in charcoal so they withstand initial herbicide treatment for noxious weeds) and targeted weed treatment. There is no grazing by domestic livestock on Juniper Hills. There are no funding partners involved in this project; however, they do have letters of support from Crooked River Watershed Council, Crook County Soil and Water Conservation District, and USDA- Forest Service Paulina Ranger District.

Glasgow Butte is located 10 miles from Richland and 12 miles from Keating. Located in the Five Mile Creek riparian area, this area has five sage-grouse leks within three miles and 10 leks within five miles of the project site.  The Glasgow Butte Watering Project is within ODFW’s Sage-grouse Core Area and NRCS’ CCPI (Cooperative Conservation Partnership Initiative).  Eagle Valley SWCD proposes to develop a spring and convey water through 2,000 feet of 2-inch to four rubber-tire troughs equipped with escape ramps. Troughs will be installed in two separate fields. OWEB funds are requested for wages/project management (<5%%), contracted services (78%), materials (3%) and administration (11%).  Two adjacent ranches are cost-share partners.

Located five miles south of Adrian, Owyhee Watershed Council (OWC) proposes to convert 40 acres from furrow-flood irrigation to sprinkler-pivot in the Blackjack Conservation Priority area. Runoff from this field flows into the Penny Drain which flows into Snake River less than one-quarter mile away.  This project proposes to install two pivots.  Project components are install: 2,780 feet of cable-con from electrical power service on Highway 201 to pivot point #2; a 10-inch flowmeter to tie into lateral; 1,220 feet of 10-inch pipe mainline for a 724-foot pivot to irrigate 21 acres; 1,100 feet of 8-inch mainline to go from pivot 1 to pivot 2 to irrigate 19 acres with a 702-foot pivot; 1,100 feet of cable con will go from pivot 2 to 1. OWEB funds are requested for wages/project management (4%), contracted services (10%), materials- pipe, bubblers, pumps (76%) and administration (10%). Price Seed farm is the cost-share partner.

column8: Hibbard Gulch Riparian & Water Quality Improvement
column27: Located seven miles northwest of Baker City at the base of the Elkhorn Mountains, Hibbard Gulch is a tributary to Salmon Creek, which is a tributary to the Powder River. The pasture is a 50-acre, winter-feeding area that flushes high amount of bacteria during spring runoff. Project components include installing 2,500 feet of 8-inch mainline to provide conveyance for wheel lines to convert from flood to sprinkler irrigation to irrigate pasture, hay and alfalfa.  Other components include:  install 2,400 feet of four-strand, wildlife-friendly fence; install 100 feet of  2-inch pipe to one tire trough and plant whips and poles along 1,800 feet total on both sides of Hibbard Gulch.  The proposed plan is for 900 poles, stock and vertical bundles to be planted at 4-foot spacing or 450 on each side of the Gulch. OWEB funds are requested for project management (4%), contracted services (32%), materials (55%) and administration (10%).  The landowner is the cost-share partner and will install the mainline, pipe, and fencing.

Located in Baker County near Halfway, this project is in the Pine Creek drainage on Lee Creek.  The primary watershed issue is poor water quality due to livestock - including 30 cattle and 8 horse - having unrestricted access to the riparian area and springs. Project components include developing two springs for year-round water; installing 1,800 feet of wildlife friendly fencing to exclude livestock from the wetland/springs; 3,200 feet of fence to split the pasture; 2,050 feet of riparian fencing to protect Lee Creek; 4 watering troughs; pipe 3,620 feet of 2-inch pipe to convey water from the spring to 3 troughs and seed the areas within the exclosure.  OWEB funds are requested for wages/project management (1%), contracted services (18%), materials (68%) and administration (11%).  The landowner is the cost-share partner providing 49% cost-share and will install pipe, fence, seeding and plantings.

The Grande Ronde Model Watershed Program (GRMW) is seeking project design funds for a section of the Wallowa River that is aggrading with increased sediment deposition. The proposed technical assistance activity is to complete an engineered project design and an archeological survey report. The engineered design and archeology report shall be used by ODFW to secure project implementation funding and to fulfill federal and state permit application requirements.  The future restoration project will also place 35 acres in a conservation easement and include riparian, floodplain and instream habitat creation. OWEB funds are requested for contracted services (91%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners include GRMW and ODFW.

An existing culvert on Lick Creek in the Wallowa-Whitman National Forest near Jospeh is a fish-passage barrier. The USFS is partnering with Wallowa Resources (WR) to design a culvert that will pass aquatic organisms. Lick Creek has miles of potential Chinook salmon, steelhead and bull trout that will be opened once the barrier is modified. The culvert will be replaced by an open-bottom structure with a simulated stream channel. OWEB funds are requested for wages (7%), contracted services (79%) and administration (13%).  USFS and Wallowa Resources are cost-share partners.  Letters of support were provided from USFS, Nez Perce Tribes (NPT), Grande Ronde Model Watershed and Wallowa County’s Natural Resources Advisory Committee (NRAC).

Harney County Watershed Council (HCWC) is seeking funds to develop an action plan.  HCWC drainages include seven 4th-field HUC’s and encompasses over 6.3 million acres in Oregon.  The basin is characterized by mountains, rivers, lakes, streams, vast high-desert sagebrush rangelands and an important agricultural hay production in the lowest portions of the basins.  Over the past 13 years, HCWC has completed all seven assessments for the various HUC’s.  An action plan will help to link these assessments to identify potential restoration opportunities. The resulting plan will be approved by both the council and OWEB.   OWEB funds are requested for contracted services (80%), production (12%) and administration (8%).  HBWC coordinator and council members will provide in-kind match.

Iron Mountain is located three miles north of Durkee in the Iron Mountain allotment.  Located within ODFW’s core sage-grouse habitat, this area has two sage-grouse leks within two miles of the project.    Three springs were developed to provide water and support grazing rotation.  The Iron Mountain Pipeline conveys water to the North and South Seeding pastures (1,209 acres) and to two troughs in the West Native Pasture (2,148 acres). The East native pasture has 1,163 acres. The pipeline is 14,118 feet long with eight trough locations. Burnt River SWCD proposes to install five 2,500-gallon storage cisterns; 500 feet of 2-inch HDPE pipe to connect the cisterns to the existing pipeline; 2,000 feet of 2-inch HDPE pipe in critical areas and two rubber-tire troughs equipped with floats and escape ramps to provide additional water sources. The grazing plan will be followed.  OWEB funds are requested for wages/project management (4%), materials (83%), administration (11%) and monitoring (1%).  The BLM and the permittees are cost-share partners.

The Pharmacy Hill Streambank Restoration project sits just outside of Jordan Valley at river mile 46 of Jordan Creek. Historical stream straightening and past grazing practices have led to streambank instability on Jordan Creek throughout the entire system. Owyhee Watershed Council (OWC) proposes to install various instream and streambank components to improve vegetation, streambank stability and water quality.  Project components include 9 juniper rootwad, 3 rock “J”-hooks with 6-inch to 40-inch diameter rock; 3 juniper rootwads at each J-hook and regrading the existing deposited gravels to create a new channel.  The vegetative portion of the project is extensive.  Native woody vegetation includes live cuttings and willow bundles, which will be collected and soaked for 7 to 10 days. OWEB funds are requested for wages/project management (11%), materials (20%),  contracted services  (61%), administration (<5%) and monitoring (1%).  The BLM and the permittees are cost-share partners.

Moore’s Hollow Upland Restoration Project is located 15 miles north of Ontario west of Interstate 84.  Portions have cheatgrass and forage kochia was planted to also act as a firebreak.  An extensive wildfire spread through the landscape approximately 20 years ago and destroyed much of the sagebrush nearby. This parcel is one of the last remaining stands of sagebrush. There are two sites for proposed restoration work.  At site one, a solar pump will replace a diesel pump and 400 feet of 2-inch pipe will access a tank for the watering system for 2,780 acres.  Site two provides water to 350 acres and also replaces a diesel pump with a solar pump; install a 1,200-gallon trough; install 2,500 feet of 2-inch pipe to convey supplemental water from the well to existing ponds.  The solar pumps will provide more reliable water pumping and increased energy efficiency.  OWEB funds are requested for wages (3%), contracted services (12%), materials (75%) and administration (8%) and monitoring (2%). The landowner is the cost-share partner.

column8: Cottonwood Creek Upland Restoration Phase II
column27: The Cottonwood Creek drainage is located north of Drewsey. The project area is comprised of three juniper removals adjacent to the 410 acres completed with the first grant.  Project components include hand removal (chainsaw) of 329 acres of juniper from three upland sites; machine-piling 214 acres, which includes 30 acres from the first project, and 155 acres of lop and scatter.  Piling will occur on with frozen or very dry ground to prevent soil disturbance and weed spread.  All disturbed area will be seeded and piles winter-burned within two years. Water will be piped from an existing spring conveying water through 3,500 feet of 1.5-inch pipe to a 1,000-gallon trough to be placed on a fence line and to serve two pastures. OWEB funds are requested for wages/project management - layout and oversight (7%), contracted services (70%), materials (12%) administration (10%) and monitoring (1%). The landowner will provide in-kind contribution.

A draw-bottom road will be moved upslope away from the riparian area in Whiskey Creek, west of la Grande. The current road is parallel to the creek, spawning and rearing habitat for ESA-listed summer Chinook and steelhead. Construction of 3,100 of the new road will be located upslope and out of the river channel and riparian area. In addition to the new road, project components include installing a 35-foot by 14-foot “I”-beam bridge with 45 Eco-blocks; eliminate 300 feet of a draw-bottom road; reconstruct 5,000 feet of the existing native-clay surface road; install five 18-inch culverts and obliterate 6,840 feet of existing road. All disturbed areas will be seeded at 10 pounds per-acre with native forest seed mix. OWEB funds are requested for contracted services (73%), materials (18%) and administration (9%). Cost-share partners are ODF and the landowner.

Prairie Creek watershed is approximately 15,000 acres of irrigated cropland and pasture with irrigation water stored in Wallowa Lake. Located six miles southeast of Joseph, this project proposes to remove 6,250 feet of open-earthen ditch providing irrigation water to 400 acres of cropland on four ownerships and replace it with 4,280 feet of mainline.Project components include installing one diversion box for the pipeline; 1,810 feet of 18-inch mainline; 1,420 feet of 12-inch mainline and 1,050 feet of 10-inch mainline. In addition, three flow meters will be installed at each pump to monitor water usage.  Livestock water will also be developed since the open ditches will be eliminated.  A total of four frost-free troughs and 2,550 feet of 1.5-inch pipe will be installed to convey water from three existing wells. OWEB funds are requested for contracted services (40%), materials (58%) and administration (<2%).  The four landowners and NRCS are cost-share partners.  Wallowa SWCD will provide project management.

column8: Alder Slope Forest Health Improvement Partnership- Weaver Creek
column27: The Alder Slope Forest Health Improvement partnership is a multi-agency, multi-landowner effort to reduce fuel loads and improve overall forest health on Alder Slope. OWEB funds are requested for 167 acres of mechanized or hand thinning to optimize spacing and reduce stand density. A masticator head will be used on areas for mechanical thinning on slopes up to 50%. Hand thinning and piling used on terrain over 50% either inaccessible or unsuitable for machinery. OWEB funds are requested for wages (<2%), contracted services (96%), administration (<2%) and monitoring (<1%).  The LO, ODF and the SWCD are cost-share partners.

column8: The Model to Protect Sage-Grouse - Site Specific Plan - Phase II
column27: The Harney County Sage-grouse CCAA Steering Committee was established in August 2011 to develop a programmatic Candidate Conservation Agreement with Assurances (CCAA) for sage-grouse on non-federal lands in Harney County. The draft CCAA for sage-grouse on private rangelands in Harney County was submitted to U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS) in June 2013. Harney SWCD (SWCD) is seeking both in-house and contract personnel with range ecology, botany and wildlife backgrounds to develop and write the site-specific plans (SSP’s) for landowners interested in enrolling in the CCAA. OWEB funds are requested for salaries (44%), travel (10%), contracted services (35%) and administration (10%). Harney SWCD, USFWS, landowners and NRCS are cost-share partners.

Runoff from a livestock feeding area and a corral drains into Fletcher Gulch which flows into the Old Owyhee Canal and onto the Malheur and Snake Rivers. Fletcher Drain runs through this property and is 50 feet from the corrals. The total length of drain to be treated is 420 feet. Malheur SWCD proposes to pipe the drain for 420 feet with a 36-inch culvert to accommodate a maximum flow of 35 cfs. OWEB funds are requested for wages/project management (1%), materials (96%) and administration (1%) and monitoring (1%). The landowner is the cost-share partner.

The Coyote Drain Water Quality Improvement project is located in the Hyline Bench Conservation Implementation Strategy Area.  The applicant is proposing to convert 80 acres from flood irrigation to pivot (64.7 acres) and solid set (15.3 acres).  Project components include installing:  200 feet of 12-inch mainline from the OID’s North Canal; 2,280 feet of 10-inch mainline to the pivot center; 5-hp pump to boost pressure for the solid-set; 3,620 feet of 6-inch mainline for the solid-set; 2,365 feet of 12-inch drain pipe; 1,305-foot pivot for 67 acres; 6-inch flowmeter; 15-hp pump for the pivot to boost pressure.  OWEB funds are requested for wages/project management (2%), contracted services (1.5%), materials (86%), administration (7%) and post-implementation status reporting (3%).  The project has 200% cost-share with the landowners providing cash and in-kind.

The Powerline Water Quality Restoration project is located in the Hyline Bench Conservation Implementation Strategy Area on 74 acres of furrow-irrigated farm ground. Water is conveyed from a box weir from a lateral that comes directly off the North Canal. The runoff is laden with nutrients, sediment and other agricultural contaminants. The applicant is proposing to convert 74 acres from flood irrigation to wheel lines.  Project components include installing:  840 feet of 8-inch mainline; 3,000 feet of 6-inch mainline; 4 wheel lines and a 6-inch flow meter. OWEB funds are requested for wages/project management (3%), materials (86%), administration (8%) and post-implementation status reporting (4%).  The project has over 200% cost-share from the landowner and NRCS.

column8: Rollin' in the Steep - Flood to Pivot
column27: Rollin’ in the Steep is located three miles northwest of Vale on 60 acres of steep, uneven farm ground. The landowner is proposing to convert from flood irrigation to sprinklers. Invasive Russian-olive and Siberian elm will also be removed along the lateral 227,piped using OWEB funds recently. Project components include installing: 1,280 feet of 10-inch pipe from the lateral to the pivot point; 1,140 feet of 8-inch pipe from the lateral center point to accommodate wheel lines in the corners; install 1,760 of #4 wire; 15-hp booster pump, electrical and pivot.OWEB funds are requested for wages (4%), contracted services (4%), materials (86%), travel (1%) and administration (5%) and post-implementation status reporting (1%). The landowner will provide cash and in-kind cost-share.

column8: Getting the Word Out and Making Things Happen in the Malheur River Basin
column27: The Malheur basin watershed has several natural resources issues.  Malheur River has the worst water quality in the state including high levels of bacteria, temperature, nutrients and sediment. Malheur Watershed Council is proposing a landowner basin-wide outreach. Activities include six bi-monthly “town hall” meetings and target members of irrigation districts, Oregon Cattlemen’s Association (OCA), Burns-Paiute Tribes (BPT), Onion Growers’ Association, Farm Bureau and others.  Planned tours include “Twilight Ag/City Tours”, “Cows and Creeks” style outreach, four other tours and three regional meetings. OWEB funds are requested for salaries (87%) and administration (13%).  Cost-share partners are DEQ 319, OSU Extension and Malheur WSC.

column8: Zumwalt Grassland Bird Habitat Integrated Restoration Project
column27: Zumwalt Prairie is the largest bunchgrass prairie remaining in North America providing habitat for a wide diversity of species. The Nature Conservancy is planning various projects in the Pine Creek watershed including protecting spring sources with buck-and-pole fencing and plantings; developing upland water sources to convey water to three 750-gallon troughs in 2 pastures creating a 660-acre riparian pasture by constructing 11,800 feet of permanent single-strand electric fence; implementing prescribed burns on 2 upland units that will each burn 125 to 150 acres and thinning conifers on on 13.5 acres. Meadow hawkweed and sulfur cinquefoil will be surveyed and treated on approximately 1,400 acres. OWEB funds are requested for wages (19%), contracted services (65%), materials (7%), administration (13%) and post-implementation monitoring (2%). Cost-share partners include TNC, Krebs Ranch and USFS.

column8: Grande Ronde Basin Stream Flow Gauging Stations Operation - Water Years 2015 & 2016
column27: The Grande Ronde Model Watershed (GRMW) is proposing to continue monitoring 12 streamflow gauges throughout Union and Wallowa Counties. The project continues the operation, maintenance, record production and review of the twelve gauges in the Grande Ronde basin.  The project intends to produce the highest quality data possible achieved through a production partnership between GRMW and OWRD.  OWRD will complete all work under contract with the GRMW.  In addition, five U.S. Forest Service (USFS) gauges characterize hydrographs for long-term monitoring of management activities on streamflow and currently provide essential data in that portion of the basin.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services (91%) and administration (9%). Cost-share partners include Bonneville Power Administration, GRMW and OWRD.

Overstreet Drain, one of five major drains to the Owyhee River, flows in at rivermile (RM) 6.  The OWEB-funded Newell pressurized pipeline services the Overstreet drain area and was fully installed in 2014.  The project proposes to install a pivot to irrigate 31 acres.  Corners will be irrigated with solid-set handlines on the remaining 8 acres.  Project components include:  installing 900 feet of cable con; 760 feet of 12-inch pipe to replace a small drainage ditch; 4,500 feet of 6-inch pipe along field borders; 6 removable steel bridges to cross Overstreet drain and a 609-foot pivot. OWEB funds are requested for wages/project management (6%), water-right transfer (3%), materials- pipe, electrical (79%), administration (9%) and monitoring (1%).  The landowner’s cost-share is 200% of the OWEB-requested amount.

Located four miles south of Adrian, Owyhee Watershed Council (OWC) proposes to convert 63 acres to permanent sprinkler-pivot. Project components include installing: 1,920 feet of cable-con; 1,260 feet of 8-inch pipe mainline from the lateral to the pivot point; 2,510 feet of 4-inch pipe from the lateral to the northeast field; 20 riser assembles in the pivot corners for handlines and a 1,218-foot Valley pivot.  OWEB funds are requested for wages/project management (4%), contracted services (10%), materials- pipe, bubblers, pumps (76%) and administration (10%). Price Seed farm has a 208% cost-share of the OWEB-requested amount.

Baker Valley SWCD is seeking funds to design a pipeline for 1.5 miles of MaHarry-Belvins Ditch (MBD) from the Wolf Creek reservoir to the P-2 connector inlet.  Baker Valley SWCD is seeking a professional engineer with expertise with hydrology, ditch practices and pipelines.  The 100% design will tie the existing P-2 pipeline to the Wolf Creek dam.  By drawing the exact amount of water needed, there will be less water withdrawn from Wolf Creek and more left for bull trout habitat in the reservoir.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services (91%) and administration (9%). Powder Valley Water Control District and Baker Valley SWCD are the cost-share partners.

This project is located near Sumpter along the McEwen Valley ditch to provide off-stream water by developing a spring and conveying water into four troughs. Once the spring is developed and livestock water provided, the McEwen Valley ditch can be closed for the winter. OWEB funds are requested for wages/project management (1%), contracted services (50%), materials (36%) and administration (13%).  The landowner is the cost-share partner providing 57% cost-share and will provide the cistern and labor for the pond.

column8: Zumwalt Prairie and Imnaha Medusahead Rye
column27: The Wallowa Canyonlands partnership (WCP) is a cooperative weed management area that protects and restores private and public canyon grasslands of the Snake, Imnaha and Lower Grande Ronde River watersheds from invasion and degradation by noxious weeds.  Project components include an aerial and ground inventory in high-risk areas to identify infestation and treatment areas; treat noxious weed infestations on 833 acres and restore degraded lands to productive plant communities after treatment.  Aerial inventory will be targeted towards Medusahead, yellow starthistle, Scotch thistle, plumeless thistle and rush skeletonweed. OWEB funds are requested for wages (13%), contracted services (48%), travel (<1%), materials (22%) and administration (13%). Cost-share partners include various landowners, BLM, Roberts Land & Cattle, TNC, Oregon Weed Board, Title II, McClaran Ranch and other landowners.

column8: Lostine River/Sheep Ridge Fish Passage Improvement
column27: The Lostine River is a major tributary to the Wallowa River and habitat to ESA-listed spring Chinook salmon, steelhead and bull trout. A diversion structure affects spring Chinook salmon and steelhead.  Spring Chinook migrate to their spawning areas between July and mid-September. Summer steelhead migrate up the Lostine in late winter and spring. Proposed  components include installing 7 full-spanning, “V”-shaped, grade-control structures; 12 rock ribs between each grade-control structure; large-scale roughness boulders 36 to 48 inches buried 60% below the stream bed and streambed simulation material to aid sediment transport.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted service (91%) and administration (9%). BPA and Grande Ronde Model Watershed Program are providing 109% cost-share.

The High Desert Youth Camp has been held for the last four years at the Great North Basin Experimental Range.  The High Desert Youth Camp targets two specific audiences.  The first is high school students who have an interest in attending college to pursue careers in natural resources and wildlife management.  The second audience is college students already enrolled in a range or natural resource program. OWEB funds are requested for wages (32%), travel (14%), materials (27%), equipment (18%) and administration (9%). Cost-share is from EOARC, OSU, ARS, Harney County Watershed Council, TNC, TVCC and private donations and is 101% of the OWEB-requested amount.

Located near Harper, an 80-acre flood-irrigated field borders the Malheur River. To eliminate the runoff from the field, the applicant proposes to install a pivot that will transport water from an existing pond. Project components include installing a 25-hp pump; electrical power and panel box; 2,240 feet of 8-inch mainline from the pond to the pivot point and a 1,060-foot Zimmatic pivot to irrigate 80 acres. OWEB funds are requested for wages/project management (4%), contracted services (3%), travel (1%), materials (83%), administration (6%) and monitoring (2%). The landowner is the cost-share partner.

The Cowboy’s Big Circle project is located in the newly created “Vale Bench Focus Area” designated recently by ODA and Malheur SWCD. Project components include installing:  900 feet of 6-inch mainline from Lateral 227; 1,660 feet of cable-con wire; electrical panel; filter; 4 bridges to cross lower lateral and install pivot on pad. OWEB funds are requested for wages/project management (5%), contracted services (4%), materials (80%), administration (8%) and post-implementation status reporting (2%). The project has 220% cost-share with the landowners and NRCS.

This project is located on Clover Creek in northwestern Malheur County.  Juniper removal is proposed on 2,000 acres (SGI); juniper removal and slash abatement on 160 acres of Clover Creek; plant 600 willow vertical bundles along 2,400 feet of streambank along Clover Creek; protect plantings with 240 juniper carcasses placed at the toe of the bank.  To enhance aspen, juniper will be removed along 2.8 miles of the riparian area (120 acres) and a machine and hand-piled juniper “fence” will protect aspen regeneration in 6 priority areas on 15 total acres.  OWEB funds are requested for wages (6%), contracted services (82%), mileage (1%), administration (9%) and post-implementation monitoring (1%). Cost-share partners are Rupp ranches and NRCS and are 208% of the OWEB-request amount.

The Malheur Basin consists of approximately 5,000 square miles in southeastern Oregon mostly in Malheur and Harney Counties.  Approximately 70% of the basin is federally owned by primarily BLM. Malheur Watershed Council (MWC) and Malheur SWCD have been monitoring the Malheur River basin intensively for many years. The sampling design and monitoring programs are being refined continually. Project components include installing 8 field stations with pressure transducers to measure water level or “stage” hourly.  Streamflow measurements will be made according to USGS methodology every 4 to 6 weeks to define the stage streamflow relation used to compute continuous streamflow record.  Selected sites are based on focus-area monitoring in Willow Creek. Criteria for the selected sites include being in a priority area; contributing to water quality issues; securable site and nearby existing gauging station. OWEB funds are requested for wages (13%), contracted services (23%), travel (5%), equipment (50%) and administration (9%).  DEQ and BOR are providing significant cost-share.

Located six miles west of Juntura in northwestern Malheur County, the applicant will remove 1,000 acres of juniper using a chainsaw.  A masticator will be used on 250 acres on slopes less than 20% to reduce heavy slash concentration.  Juniper boles will be shredded by a rotary head mounted on a tracked vehicle.  In addition, 40 acres of isolated Medusahead patches will be sprayed with PlateauTM at a rate of 6 ounces per-acre.  After a full year, broadcast seed (15 lbs/acre) will be applied with a mixture of Siberian, tall, bluebunch and crested wheatgrass, Sherman’s big bluegrass and sheep fescue.  OWEB funds are requested for wages/project management (6%), contracted services - juniper removal (78%), materials -seed (4%) and administration (9%).  The landowner is the cost-share partner of 47%.

Powder Basin Watershed council (PBWC) hopes to engage more community members and agency partners in the process of developing a basin-wide strategic plan that will govern the council’s efforts to address limiting factors over the next 10 years. PBWC also wishes to increase public awareness and participation in council activities. Project products include a quarterly print and electronic newsletter; four informal meetings in communities not currently represented by members; direct mailing to 10% of households; social media and website development. OWEB funds are requested for wages (81%), travel (<1%), other (16%), administration (1%) and equipment (<1%).  Meyer Memorial Trust will provide 33% cost-share.

PBWC is seeking technical assistance for 2.3 miles of the lower reaches of Clear Creek along these seven ownerships. The resulting restoration project will address in-stream habitat improvement, grazing and wildlife management concerns and provide a plan to address increasing channel complexity and riparian health. In addition, there will be a suite of options for replacing the diversions. The engineering firm will need experience with fish passage, bank stabilization, habitat, floodplain issues, hydrologic experience and riparian enhancement.  OWEB funds are requested for wages/salaries (13%), contracted services (84%), travel (1%) and administration (<1%).  Jubitz Family Foundation, Collins foundation, PBWC and council volunteers will provide cash and in-kind cost-share.

Malheur County SWCD formed a steering committee in February 2014 with the purpose of developing a Candidate Conservation Agreement with Assurances (CCAA) for the greater sage-grouse on private range land in Malheur County. Malheur SWCD, in coordination with USFWS and other partners, started work on several site-specific plans (SSP’s). Staff are needed to prepare the SSP's. OWEB funds are requested for salaries (88%), travel (1%) materials (6%), and administration (5%). Malheur County Sage-grouse Steering Committee, NRCS and OSU Extension are cost-share partners.

The Parsnip Peak Invasive Annuals project area encompasses 10,860 acres of State land (5,332 acres) and private (5,528 acres) in the sagebrush-steppe rangeland eight miles south of Jordan Valley.  Efforts to improve rangeland health complements on-going juniper control effort.  NRCS awarded a $250,000 grant for the Parsnip Peak Invasive Annual Conservation Implementation Strategy (CIS).   Rangeland inventory will occur on 10,860 acres of private and State-owned land and include a combination of on-the-ground and remote sensing. OWEB funds are requested for wages (11%), contracted services (54%), travel (2%), materials (19%), administration (9%) and monitoring (5%). Cost-share partners include landowners, USFWS and NRCS and cost-share is 416% of the OWEB-request.

The Bench Ground project is located seven miles east of Vale on 38 acres of farm ground.  Crops are currently flood-irrigated. Project components include installing:  200 feet of 8-inch pipe; a 5-foot bubbler; 1,010 feet of 6-inch pipe installed from the bubbler to the pivot point; 1,515 feet of cable-in conduit from the 3-phase power to the pivot point; 1,025 feet of cable-in conduit from pivot point to pump located at the bubbler; 20-hp permanent pump and 200 feet of 8-inch pipe from the water source to the bubbler.  OWEB funds are requested for wages (5%), contracted services (16%), materials (68%), travel (4%) and administration (7%).  The landowner will provide cash and in-kind cost-share of 253% of the OWEB-requested amount.

column8: Continuing the War on Weeds in the Owyhee
column27: The Jordan Valley Coordinated Weed Management Area (JVCWMA) has been working in the upper Owyhee watershed for over eight years. Project components include education/outreach with the Winter Weed Seminar; Owyhee Field Day; landowner consultations, CWMA board meetings, Annual Weed Work Day and other partner events. OWEB funds are requested for wages (63%), contracted services (6%), travel/mileage (6%), materials (7%), equipment (4%) and administration (13%) and monitoring (1%). Cost-share partners include basin landowners, Oregon State Weed Board, ODFW, BLM, DSL, Malheur County, ODOT and Jordan Valley Irrigation District.  Cost-share for the OWEB-requested amount is 218%.

column8: Wallowa Resources' Watershed Evaluation Teams (WET) Program
column27: Wallowa Resources (WR), based in Enterprise, initiated a watershed evaluation team (WET) program designed to provide hands-on experience in data collection that builds environmental awareness for students several years ago. The WET Program reaches  approximately 150 students and 8 teachers in Wallowa County. This program targets 6th, 10th and 11th grade school students in Wallowa County. OWEB funds are requested for wages (83%), supplies (2%), travel (1%) and administration (13%). USFWS, the Nez Perce Tribes (NPT), ODFW, Wallowa SWCD, Wallowa County schools and landowners are cost-share partners.  Positive letters of support were provided by USFWS and NPT.

This project is located 24 miles west of Vale in the Willow Creek drainage and will convert 57 acres from furrow-flood irrigation to sprinkler. Project components include installing 3,260 feet of 8-inch pipe for mainline; install a 1,168 Zimmatic pivot to irrigate 57 acres; 3,260 feet of cable con; a 20-HP pump for the pivot; an 8-inch flowmeter to the pivot and a 10-inch flowmeter from the canal to the pond.  In addition, a willow test plot will be planted along 240 feet of Willow Creek. OWEB funds are requested for wages (10%), contracted services (17%), materials (64%) and administration (8%). The landowner and NRCS will cost-share 186% of the OWEB-requested amount.

column8: Mike Williams Chesnimnus Fencing and Off-Site Water Development
column27: Chesnimnus Creek, a tributary to Joseph Creek (RM 49.8), is a major wild summer steelhead  stream in the Grande Ronde basin northeast of Enterprise.  Project components include constructing one mile of 4-strand, barbed-wire, non-continuous fence along section of Chesnimnus Creek; installing two solar livestock watering systems; pump, 48-inch, 10-foot ling culvert and trough.  OWEB funds are requested for  contracted services (36%), materials- pipe, pumps (50%) and administration (13%). ODFW is the cost-share partner and the landowner will provide long-term fence maintenance.

The Alkali Forage Reserve Restoration project is located 30 miles south of Burns on the BLM’s Alkali allotment. The allotment is part of a pipeline network that includes 13 allotments, watering more than 60,000 acres with 100 miles of pipe. The proposed solution is to improve water and forage availability by:  installing 31,680 feet of pipeline; two tire troughs; install a 10,000-gallon storage tank and inter-seed 3,000 acres. OWEB funds are requested for wages (2%), contracted services (21%), materials- pipe, seed (72%) and administration (5%). BLM is the cost-share partner at 35% of the OWEB-requested amount.

Ducks Unlimited and partners from the Harney Basin Wetlands Initiative (HBWI) are seeking a position to conduct landowner outreach and provide technical support to the SONEC (Southern Oregon-Northeast California) area. This is a collaborative partnership with NRCS, Ducks Unlimited, Intermountain Joint Venture, USFWS’ Malheur National Wildlife Refuge and HBWI to further conservation delivery in the Harney basin, a priority subbasin of the SONEC waterfowl priority areas.  There is a lack of capacity for landowner outreach for various programs include the Farm Bill programs obligated to enhance flood-irrigation structure: Oregon NRCS Working Lands for Waterbirds Conservation Implementation Strategy and Conservation Effects Assessment Project. Cost-share (cash) will be provided from NRCS, DU, Intermountain Joint Venture and USFWS- Malheur National Wildlife Refuge to fund this position.  OWEB funds are requested for wages (87%) and administration (13%).

This project is proposed for Kangaroo Basin, one of three forks located in the SE corner of Wheeler County headwaters of Rattlesnake Creek. Over three and a half miles of Rattlesnake Creek is identified by ODFW as steelhead habitat. The headwater basin is choked with juniper that directly impacts the natural hydrograph, both in groundwater sources and the interception of limited precipitation. Also, as juniper communities become denser, erosion and sediment movement becomes a problem as grass and shrubs in the landscape die-off and there is nothing to hold the soil during rain events. By strategically removing juniper in this headwater site, increased stream flow would improve over six additional miles of potential spawning and rearing habitat for Redband and ESA summer steelhead. Using a tracked feller-buncher, approximately 276 acres of encroaching juniper would be pulled and piled. Sites that are rocky or extremely steep will not be treated, allowing a more natural mosaic of habitat for wildlife. The treatment sites selected are located on north-facing, deeper soils that still exhibit good perennial and shrub component. Partners on the project include the landowner and the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs (CTWS).

This project, located on The Nature Conservancy’s Dunstan Preserve on the Middle Fork John Day River in Grant County, will re-establish stream flow connection with two side channels and adjacent floodplain. Currently, these two channels only carry water at peak flows in the early spring. One of the main limiting factors for salmonids, steelhead and Bull trout abundance is adequate juvenile habitat and cool water pockets in the mainstem of the Middle Fork John Day River. The primary objective of the project is to improve juvenile rearing habitat, increase channel complexity, enhance floodplain connectivity and improve overall aquatic habitat in cool water refugia areas by utilizing the established vegetation shade along those historic channels.  Partners on this project include the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs, Bureau of Reclamation, USFWS and The Nature Conservancy.

column6: Upper South Fork John Day WC
column27: The Upper South Fork Watershed Council (USFJDWC), expanding to include the entire South Fork John Day River Watershed in Grant County, requires financial assistance to complete an Action Plan that will include a watershed inventory of both potential and completed projects, partnership development and prioritization of significant areas or project types in their watershed. The Action Plan will be a working document, regularly updated to record challenges, priorities, opportunities and activities the watershed council would like to address. It will describe the council’s goals and objectives, public engagement efforts, and funding strategies for each activity. Partnerships on this effort include ODFW, NRCS, Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs, Grant SWCD and the South Fork John Day Watershed Council.

column6: Upper South Fork John Day WC
column8: South Fork Upland Initiative - Johnnie's and Caps Creek Aspen Restoration
column27: The two project sites are located on Johnnie’s Creek and Caps Creek in the Upper South Fork John Day River Basin in the south end of Grant County. These Aspen stands have drastically declined in productivity due to encroaching conifer and junipers, and grazing pressure from feral horse herds and large elk populations. Aspens are an important habitat to avian and terrestrial wildlife, as well as to the overall watershed function. Many of these drainages are prone to flashy storm events that aspen can defuse and disperse the energy and reduce or eliminate erosion and downcutting.  The project proposes to remove encroaching conifer and juniper on three (3) acres at two aspen sites. Once cleared, then build over 2,000 feet of buck and pole fencing to protect from grazing pressures. This project would add to other aspen restoration projects funded by NRCS on this same ranch for a total of over 10 acres of protected aspen. Partners on this project include the landowner and manager, NRCS and the South Fork John Day Watershed Council.

column8: Fox & Cottonwood Leafy Spurge Control - Phase II
column27: Leafy Spurge is a non-native noxious weed, introduced in the seventies and now flourishing in the Fox Creek and Cottonwood Creek Basins of Grant County. Dominating and out-competing native riparian vegetation, it uses streams and floodwaters to disperse seeds downstream. This proposal is the second phase, continuing the work of a previously funded OWEB project scheduled for completion at the end of the year. Multiple agencies and landowners are concerned with the downstream spread and extent of the Leafy spurge infestation. Leafy spurge impairs riparian health, wildlife habitat and diverse native plant communities. It is considered toxic and can reduce rangeland and wildlife carrying capacity by 50 to 75%.  This proposal will pay for herbicide treatments on the 600 foot buffer along the entire reach of Fox and Cottonwood Creeks, extending the effectiveness of prior treatments on approximately 300 acres. Partners on this project include the North Fork John Day Watershed Council, Grant SWCD, Title II funds, Grant County Road Department and private landowners.

column8: Fox & Cottonwood Leafy Spurge Control - Phase II - EM
column27: Leafy Spurge is a non-native noxious weed, introduced in the seventies and now flourishing in the Fox Creek and Cottonwood Creek Basins of Grant County. Dominating and out-competing native riparian vegetation, it uses streams and floodwaters to disperse seeds downstream. This proposal is the effectiveness monitoring component of the second phase, continuing the work of a previously funded OWEB project scheduled for completion at the end of the year. Multiple agencies and landowners are concerned with the downstream spread and extent of the Leafy spurge infestation. Leafy spurge impairs riparian health, wildlife habitat and diverse native plant communities. It is considered toxic and can reduce rangeland and wildlife carrying capacity by 50 to 75%. This proposal will pay for continued effectiveness monitoring along the treatment area on Fox and Cottonwood Creeks, extending the effectiveness of prior treatments on approximately 300 acres. Partners on this project include the North Fork John Day Watershed Council, Grant SWCD, Title II funds, Grant County Road Department and private landowners.

column8: Upper South Fork John Day Riparian Fence Project
column27: This project is located along the Upper South Fork John Day River in the southern end of Grant County. Unrestricted livestock access and high water events have impaired riparian vegetation and created conditions conducive to high amounts of sediment entering the SF John Day River. This proposal seeks cost share funding to install 1.4 miles of riparian fence to better manage livestock in riparian meadow and build three hardened water crossings to facilitate livestock movement and provide a reliable water source. Partners on the project are the landowner and the Grant SWCD.

column8: Lower Cottonwood Fish Passage Improvements - Phase II - POD #10
column27: This project is located on Cottonwood Creek, a significant tributary of the North Fork John Day River outside the town of Monument in Grant County. Cottonwood Creek is listed as critical habitat for ESA listed Mid-Columbia summer steelhead. The applicant, in partnership with the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs, conducted an assessment of the lower four miles of stream, to determine fish passage and overall condition of twelve irrigation diversions (PODs). The resulting assessment included designs to correct erosion and fish passage at three existing sheet piling irrigation structures. POD #10, the subject of this proposal, has degraded to the point that it now presents a barrier to all life stages of steelhead and other aquatic species at low flows and a jump height issue for juveniles the rest of the time. Phase one is funded and will correct POD barrier #1. The components to remedy this barrier at POD #10 include installation of large boulder grade control structure, engineered streambed and log structure for instream habitat. A low-flow weir will be added to the top of the existing sheet steel to increase flow depth during low flow periods. Noxious weed control will be conducted both before and after construction activities to reduce infestation.  A water right transfer will be required since the existing structure location doesn’t match what is shown on Oregon Water Resources Department maps. The applicant has engaged the local watermaster and the relevant water users to resolve this situation. Partners on this project include Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs, ODFW, USFWS and the Monument SWCD.

column8: Lower Cottonwood Fish Passage Improvements - Phase II - POD #8
column27: This project is located on Cottonwood Creek, a significant tributary of the North Fork John Day River outside the town of Monument in Grant County. Cottonwood Creek is listed as critical habitat for ESA listed Mid-Columbia summer steelhead. The applicant, in partnership with the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs, conducted an assessment of the lower four miles of stream, to determine fish passage and overall condition of twelve irrigation diversions (PODs). The resulting assessment included designs to correct erosion and fish passage at three existing sheet piling irrigation structures. POD #8, the subject of this proposal, has degraded to the point that it now presents a barrier to all life stages of steelhead and other aquatic species at low flows and a jump height issue for juveniles the rest of the time. Similar to the fix at POD #10, the components to remedy this barrier at POD #8 include installation of large boulder grade control structure, engineered streambed and log structure for instream habitat. A low-flow weir will be added to the top of the existing sheet pilings to increase flow depth during low flow periods. Noxious weed control will be conducted both before and after construction activities to reduce infestation. A water right transfer will be required since the existing structure location doesn’t match what is shown on Oregon Water Resources Department maps. The applicant has engaged the local watermaster and the relevant water users to resolve this situation. Partners on this project include Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs (CTWS), ODFW, USFWS and the Monument SWCD.

column8: Bull Run Tailing Restoration Technical Assistance
column27: This project is located on Bull Run Creek outside the town of Granite in east Umatilla County. Bull Run Creek and its tributaries have been designated as critical habitat for ESA listed steelhead and bull trout and also supports Chinook, Redband trout and other native aquatic species. It has been severely impacted by historic mining activity where dredge tailings constrict the channel and disconnect it from the natural floodplain. Bull Run Creek is listed as a 303(d) water quality limited stream due to temperature and sedimentation. This technical assistance application would fund a plan and design a system to remove the tailing piles and restore a natural stream channel and floodplain connection. Success would be measured by a resulting NEPA document and restoration project designs. Partners on this venture include the Confederated Tribes Umatilla Indian Reservation, Wallowa Whitman National Forest, and the North Fork John Day Watershed Council.

This incentive-based proposal has ten specific project sites within Sherman County. Sherman County is one of Oregon’s major dryland wheat producing areas with the highest percentage of tillable acres of any county in the state. Cropland can be vulnerable to wind erosion as well as sheet and rill erosion during storm events. Conventional tillage systems has been the primary management practice in this area with producers installing conservation measures such as terraces, grass waterways and water and sediment control basins (WASCBs) to mitigate soil leaving their fields. However, many producers have seen their neighbor’s direct seeded fields hold while their own fields have ditches and traces of erosion. Because of expensive seeding equipment and a change in overall management procedures, many producers are hesitant to invest a lot of money before they give direct seed a try. This proposal will provide cost-share to direct seed 500 acres on ten different farms, new to the direct seed method, for a total of 5,278 acres impacted. Partners on this project include ten landowners/producers, the Sherman SWCD and the Sherman County Area Watershed Council.

column8: Birch Creek Assessment and Action Plan - Landowner Outreach
column27: Funds are requested for conducting the public involvement process associated with preparation of the Birch Creek Assessment & Action Plan. Birch Creek is an important tributary to the Umatilla River and provides critical habitat to ESA listed summer steelhead. The actual assessment & action plan will be funded by the Confederated Tribes of Umatilla Indian Reservation (CTUIR). It is crucial that landowners and other interested parties in this mix of rural residential and urban watershed have their interests addressed and have the opportunity to learn the technical aspects of restoration and watershed health. This public involvement process, facilitated by the Umatilla Basin Watershed Council, will help local landowners and other interested parties understand restoration efforts with the goal they will ultimately support the implementation of restoration as identified in the Assessment and Action Plan. Partners on this project are CTUIR and the Umatilla Basin Watershed Council.

This project is located on Wildhorse Creek, a tributary of the Umatilla River, in the town of Athena in Umatilla County. The focus of the project is to evaluate the feasibility of removing or modifying a 7-8 foot fish passage barrier underneath the Athena City Bridge by facilitating stakeholder meetings, doing hydrological analysis and developing conceptual designs. Partners include the ODFW, Confederated Tribes of Umatilla Indian Reservation, the City of Athena and the Umatilla Basin Watershed Council.

column8: Dillon Dam Removal: Phase II - Pipeline
column27: This project, a component of removing the Dillon Dam, is located on the Umatilla River, near the town of Echo in Umatilla County. Before the dam can be removed a pipeline must be installed and functioning so the water right transfer to the Westland Canal can be proved up. This project, following a technical assistance grant (214-6024) to fund the pipeline design, will install 11,000 feet of 21” pipeline, a headgate, flow meter and trash screen where the water is diverted from the Westland Canal. Project partners on the project are the Dillon Irrigation Company and the Umatilla Basin Watershed Council.

column8: Lower Bridge - Bear Habitat Water Quality Phase #3
column27: This project is located on private land along Bridge Creek and Bear Creek, both important ESA listed steelhead and Chinook tributaries to the John Day River in Wheeler County. A large portion of Bridge and Bear Creek is not fenced and livestock have access to the stream. The riparian vegetation in these unfenced sections consists primarily of Russian olive and knapweed, and lacks habitat complexity, stream shading, and floodplain connectivity. The landowner also has to maintain a stream crossing to access farm fields on the east side of Bridge Creek. Finally, a feedlot and adjacent ditch, during heavy precipitation events, conveys runoff directly into Bridge Creek causing significant water quality concerns. Phase three will address one mile of Bridge Creek above and below the confluence with Bear Creek, as well as focusing some restoration on the lower end of Bear Creek. A total of four miles of riparian fence will be installed; the entire area treated for the removal of Russian olive; channel modifications implemented to re-engage historic meanders; a bridge installed to eliminate crossing the stream directly; 3,200 feet of heavy fence installed along the lower side of the feedlot; and a berm/bioswale installed to disconnect the feedlot from Bridge Creek. Partners on this project include the landowner and the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs.

column8: Mid John Day - Bridge Creek Watershed Council Action Plan
column27: This technical assistance project will be instrumental in the development of the Mid John Day Bridge Creek Watershed Council (MJDBCWC) action plan. Two assessments and one reach evaluation have been completed on the Butte, Bridge and Mountain Creek watersheds within the MJDBCWC boundaries. Information gathered from those assessments, existing council goals and priorities, and various partner agency priorities will be compiled into a five-year Action Plan document to help identify and prioritize restoration efforts with the Council boundaries. Partners invited to contribute to the action plan development include: NRCS, BLM, USFS, ODA, ODFW, OSU Extension, Wheeler County, Wheeler SWCD and private landowners.

This project is located on the Pine Creek watershed in northwestern Wheeler County. This watershed has been inundated with western juniper and is facing threats from invasive annual grass species as well. Historic grazing management and fire suppression has encouraged juniper and winter annuals to encroach on sites and threaten native perennial grasses and shrubs. This project will complement previous projects on neighboring properties, including the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs Pine Creek Conservation Area. A recent turn-over in this property ownership has brought this restoration opportunity that includes the removal of juniper on 350 acres of prioritized sites (north facing, deep soil slopes), develop seven springs to provide off-channel upland water sources for both livestock and wildlife, treat 60 acres of annual grass infestation by herbicide and reseeding, and install 5,700 feet of cross fence to help improve the ability to manage livestock grazing in the uplands. Partners on the project include the landowner and the Mid John Day Bridge Creek Watershed Council.

column6: Upper South Fork John Day WC
column27: This project will, by using aerial maps and GIS analysis, locate and survey significant aspen communities in the Upper South Fork John Day River basin. Once sites are located via GIS, data will be collected on stand vigor, number and type of conifers, structures present, photo documentation and potential restoration identified by cruising each location. OSU specialists will provide training in understanding requirements for healthy aspen communities both through consultation and a public workshop. Partners on this project include private landowners, the Upper South Fork of the John Day River Watershed Council, the Bureau of Land Management, ODFW, NRCS, Grant SWCD, the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs, and the USFS.

column6: Upper South Fork John Day WC
column27: This project is located on Sheep Creek, an intermittent tributary of the South Fork John Day River near Izee in south Grant County.  Due to fire suppression, juniper has encroached into riparian areas, aspen groves and is depleting springs and streams of their normal function and flow.  Historic grazing and wild ungulates have kept aspen from regenerating to a multi-age class canopy. The project will stimulate aspen clone production and protect 12 acres with buck and pole fencing, remove 190 acres of encroaching juniper on the hill slopes around the meadow and in the aspen groves, develop two upland springs for livestock water and treat 90 acres of noxious weeds. Partners on the project include the ranch owner, the Upper South Fork John Day Watershed Council, the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs, and Grant SWCD.

This proposal seeks funding for an assessment of hydrologic and geomorphic processes and identification of alternative solutions for the Greasewood watershed near Helix in Umatilla County. Greasewood Creek originates at the top of a 5,200 acre basin of intensively managed agricultural lands, flowing past Helix and into Wildhorse Creek, a tributary of the Umatilla River. Historic farming practices have altered the natural processes of Greasewood Creek, creating issues with high sediment loads, channelization, degraded floodplains and flooding. Land management practices have significantly improved in recent years, shifting toward conservation tillage, crop rotations and enrollment in CREP but the sediment routing issues continue. The assessment will include alternatives to restore natural channel and floodplain form and morphology, restore floodplain connectivity and improve flood attenuation through a range of high flow events, restore historic hydrologic regime and a more naturalized hydrograph, decrease channel erosion, and improve sediment and flow routing. Numerous partners support this project, including a long list of landowners in the basin, Natural Resource Conservation Service, Oregon Department of Agriculture, Oregon Department of Transportation, the City of Helix, Helix Parks and Recreation, Umatilla County and the Umatilla County SWCD.

This project site is on 13,400 acres in northern Grant County including 10 miles of Desolation Creek before it flows into the North Fork of the John Day River. The project will address degraded wet meadow and spring habitat in order to re-establish flow and improve habitat. On the property, abundant springs and their associated wet-meadow habitats have been unprotected and degraded by decades of intensive grazing and logging. Where flow once contributed to Desolation Creek, several springs are trampled to the extent that water is pooling in hoof-prints rather than running toward the waterway. Springs and outflow channels have been stripped of protective vegetation causing channel incision and riparian degradation. Associated aspen stands are in decline and over-dense forests are encroaching on these wet-meadow ecosystems. This proposal includes installing 8,448 feet of fencing around wet meadows, developing five springs with off-site water for livestock, thinning six acres of encroaching forest thickets and protecting two stands of aspen. Partners on this project include Desolation Creek LLC, Umatilla National Forest, North Fork John Day Watershed Council, Confederated Tribes of the Umatilla Indian Reservation, and the Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife.

This project is located in northern Sherman County, one of the major wheat producing areas in the state. Cropland can be vulnerable to sheet and rill erosion during extreme weather events such as rain on snow or flashy rain storms. This erosion causes excessive sediment transport into natural draws and swales resulting in degraded water quality as it reaches perennial streams. To resolve this issue, this project would install terraces and water and sediment control basins (WASCBs) on cropland slopes to catch and slow down overland flows, dropping out sediment before it reaches live water. Project components include building 11,970 feet of terrace and 15 cropland WASCBS. Partners on this project include Sherman Co Area Watershed Council, Sherman SWCD, NRCS and the landowner.

This proposal seeks funding to hire leaders and instructors for a county-wide program integrating high school age students in restoration activities and on-the-ground learning. Maintaining a healthy ecosystem requires both current and a long-term commitment. By involving youth in restoration now, they not only take those lessons back home but also into their future. Partners in this program include the Oregon Youth Conservation Corp (OYCC), Oregon Community Foundation, the North Fork John Day Watershed Council and the USFS.

column8: STELLAR Watershed Education and Community Outreach
column27: This program, focusing in the Milton Freewater area in Umatilla County, will increase both student and adult understanding of why healthy streams and adjoining riparian and upland zones are critical to salmon and steelhead habitat. Over 500 students and 100 adults will be involved in multiple program activities that aim to educate on the status of Salmon and steelhead, and local issues that contribute to the need for restoration. Activities include hands-on restoration involvement by both students and adults. Partners on this program include the Walla Walla Basin Watershed Council, the Milton-Freewater Unified School District, the Wildhorse Foundation, the Blue Mountain Foundation, Diack Ecology, and many volunteers.

column8: Meredith Diversion Nos. 1 and 2 Replacement Project
column27: This project, located on Beech Creek in Grant County, seeks funding to consolidate two irrigation diversions into a single, fish-friendly structure. Beech Creek is an important steelhead spawning and juvenile Chinook rearing tributary of the John Day River. The two existing structures currently impede fish passage for some life stages of salmonids during critical times of the year. Partners on this project include the landowner, Bureau of Reclamation and the Grant SWCD.

This project is located within the Bear Creek sub-watershed of the Silvies River basin in southeast Grant County. Aspen stands and a wet meadow site within the project area have been degraded due to conifer encroachment, as well as domestic and wild ungulate grazing. This proposal seeks funding to treat four aspen communities totaling 5 acres to promote tree regeneration, construct livestock exclusion and management fencing on both aspen (5 acres) and wet meadows (32 acres) and establish six spring development water sources to serve new pasture units. Partners on this project include Grant SWCD and the landowner.

The project sites are located in the northern drainages of the Middle Fork John Day River, near Galena in Grant County. Big Creek, East Fork Big Creek, Pizer Creek, Lost Creek and Deadwood Creek and a series of six wet meadows within these drainages present a mixture of limiting factors. These creeks provide core spawning and rearing habitat for Bull Trout, Steelhead and Chinook salmon. However, the habitat which supports these species has been detrimentally altered due to historic logging, grazing, mining, beaver trapping, road construction and homesteads. The six meadows identified as project sites currently have gullies that drain erosive overland flow, rather than allowing it to soak into the ground. The proposed streams are over-stocked with encroaching conifers and have issues with floodplain connectivity and channel simplification evident by reduced large wood recruitment and low diversity in riparian vegetation. The proposed treatment will drop or tip select trees into the riparian zone, opening up the canopy for riparian hardwoods to re-establish and the large wood adding roughness to both channel and floodplain; and thin portions of conifer encroachment into meadows and place coarse, woody debris in eroding gullies to catch sediment and hold-back overland flows. Partners on this project include the North Fork John Day Watershed Council and the Malheur National Forest.

This project is located on Cottonwood Creek in northwest Grant County near the town of Monument. After the completion of an extensive assessment and prioritization of fish passage barriers on the lower twelve miles of Cottonwood Creek, Monument SWCD and partners have begun to correct those at the top of the list. Four sites were identified as top priorities – three have been completed or are in the process of being corrected - this proposal would correct the fourth and final of the highest priority sites. This project would consolidate two irrigation push-up dams that pose a barrier for juvenile steelhead and Chinook attempting to seek refuge in the upper Cottonwood Creek basin from the warmer waters of the North Fork John Day River. One of these diversions currently supplies water to an unscreened open irrigation ditch that has the high potential to strand fish in the field. Additionally, the other diversion conveyance is over 1,000’ of leaky above-ground mainline which loses a significant amount of water during transport to the field.   The project proposes to combine the two points of diversions into one fish-friendly rock weir-style diversion structure so the two push-up dams can be abandoned. ODFW will install a fish screen at the new diversion site that will exclude fish from both irrigation systems. The leaking, above-ground mainline will be replaced with 1,200’ of buried PVC pipe. Partners on the project include the Monument SWCD, ODFW, Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs, USFWS Partners Program and the landowner.

This proposal seeks funding for a multi-pronged approach to reach 175 students, 40 landowners/managers and 1,000 members of the general public. The program is based out of Wheeler County and will use workshops, hands-on activities linked to restoration projects, an interactive streamtable and a kiosk to increase knowledge and understanding of the value of healthy, functioning natural systems in the watershed. Partners on this proposal include the Mid John Day Bridge Creek Watershed Council, the Wheeler SWCD, OSU Extension and Wheeler County schools.

This project is located along Butte Creek, a tributary of the John Day River in northwest Wheeler County. Four fish passage barriers, located above the town of Fossil, restrict upstream connectivity to good steelhead habitat. Currently three undersized, failing and/or perched culverts and one headcut are barriers to fish movement. This section of Butte Creek has undergone quite a bit of restoration - all four sites are either enrolled in CREP or are fenced to exclude the riparian areas from grazing. The three culverts will be replaced with bottomless pipe arch culverts that meet ODFW fish passage requirements for steelhead. The passage at the headcut will be corrected by installing a stream simulation riffle to create a stable transition between the two elevations and provide fish passage at all flows. Partners on this project include the Wheeler SWCD and the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs.

This project is located on Badger Creek, an upper steelhead tributary of the John Day River in southeast Wheeler County. This is the third highest diversion in the Mountain Creek watershed and it was identified as a fish passage barrier in the Mountain Creek Reach Evaluation/Action Plan.  The open ditch downstream of the diversion is in close proximity to the stream and can breach causing negative water quality. The diversion will be replaced with a stream simulated diversion that will provide passage for all life stages of fish at all flows. The area immediately around the diversion will be fenced. 1,500 feet of the open ditch near the stream will be replaced with buried pipe. There is already a functioning fish screen on location but a flow measuring device will be built on the downstream end to facilitate better water management. Partners on the project include Wheeler SWCD and the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs.

This project is located on Indian Creek, a high elevation tributary of Badger Creek and Mountain Creek, in southeast Wheeler County. Mountain Creek becomes Rock Creek before it enters the John Day River. This property has three diversions on Indian Creek that are used for irrigation. None of the existing diversions allow for fish passage, are screened or have flow measuring devices installed. Currently, passage can be totally blocked depending on the flow and irrigation demands. In the past, ditch failure and overtopping have degraded water quality instream. The project will replace the upper and middle diversions with fish-friendly structures, install fish screens and flow measuring devices, convert 4,100 feet of ditch to pipe and totally abandon the lowest diversion. The water right allows water to be diverted from any of the three points of diversion, so no water right transfers are needed. Partners on this project include the Wheeler SWCD, NRCS and the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs.

column8: Headwaters of Bridge Creek Watershed Improvement
column27: This project is located in southeast Wheeler County, in the Bridge Creek watershed which drains into the John Day River. The combination of invasive species encroachment in the riparian area, loss of native vegetation, juniper/ponderosa pine encroachment into historic grasslands, past land use practices, and fire suppression has created a decline in quality upland habitat and reduced water quantity and quality in the headwaters of the Bridge Creek basin. This project seeks funds to remove 400 acres of juniper, pre-commercial thin 55 acres of Ponderosa pine, and reseed 180 acres mechanically disturbed during juniper removal process.  This is just one part of a landscape scale treatment that will result in over 3,585 acres of juniper removed, 375 acres of forest stand improvements, 10 miles of Bridge Creek and 268 acres of riparian zone enrolled in FSA’s Conservation Reserve Enhancement Program (CREP) and a follow-up prescribed burn schedule to keep juniper from re-establishing. Partners on this project include two landowners, Wheeler SWCD, NRCS and the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs.

column6: Upper South Fork John Day WC
column8: John Day River Sub-Yearling Spring Chinook Salmon Monitoring to Enhance Population Productivity
column27: Juvenile Spring Chinook salmon in the Upper Mainstem John Day River encounter density dependent limitations on rearing space. Density dependence restricts production of yearling fish migrants, hence limits adult abundance. Little is known about the abundance, distribution and physiology of downstream rearing juvenile Chinook in the John Day River basin. Monitoring this life history will help focus on restoration projects that benefit juvenile rearing habitat. The monitoring sites are located in both the lower South Fork John Day River and mainstem John Day River in Grant County. Partners include the Upper South Fork of the John Day Watershed Council, Oregon State University and ODFW.
